revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=June 2018}} '''AEDIPS''', the '''Association of Educational Development and Improvement Professionals in Scotland''' is an association that supports the development of [[education in Scotland]], with a particular focus on [[entitlement]] and quality.
Formerly known as the '''AEAS''' (the '''Association of Educational Advisers in Scotland'''), AEDIPS updated its [[constitution]] and its name in 2005 to reflect the changing roles of professionals working in the areas of quality improvement, [[curriculum]], and professional development in Scottish education today.
AEDIPS acts as a forum for the approximate five hundred educational professionals now supporting schools in all sectors of education in the areas of improvement, curriculum, and professional development in local authorities in Scotland.
Membership of AEDIPS is open to permanent staff, secondees, [[consultants]], and former improvement and development professionals who may have moved on from local authority work but wish to keep up with educational developments in Scotland.
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070311032029/http://www.aedips.org.uk/ AEDIPS website]
[[Category:Educational administration]] [[Category:Educational organisations in Scotland]]
{{UK-edu-stub}}

{{Use Australian English|date=June 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Angela Bennett | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = ''circa'' {{Birth year and age|1945}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Australian | other_names = | occupation = Mining heiress | known_for = | relations = [[Michael Wright (Australian businessman)|Michael Wright]] (brother, 1937–2012) | children = Seven | net_worth = {{increase}} {{AUD}}1.55 bn {{small|(2014 [[BRW Rich 200|''BRW'']])}}
{{increase}} {{USD}}1.01 bn {{small|(2014 ''[[Forbes]]'')}} }} '''Angela Bennett''' (born ''circa'' 1945) is an [[Australia]]n mining heiress and businesswoman.{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/angela-bennett/ |title=#25 Angela Bennett |work=Australia's 50 Richest |publisher=[[Forbes]] |date=January 2014 |accessdate=29 June 2014 }}{{cite news |author=Wilson-Chapman, Amy |url=http://www.perthnow.com.au/business/local-business/iron-ore-heir-and-rinehart-foe-michael-wright-passes-away/story-e6frg2s3-1226341129173 |title=Iron ore heir and Rinehart foe Michael Wright passes away |work=[[The Sunday Times (Western Australia)|The Sunday Times]] |location=Perth, WA |date=28 April 2012 }}{{cite news |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/billion-dollar-war/story-e6frg6pf-1111113121768 |title=Billion-dollar war |work=[[The Australian]] |date=9 March 2007 }}{{cite news |author=Hernandez, Vittorio |url=http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/388471/20120927/mining-queens-gina-rinehart-angela-bennett-legal.htm#.UP5Yl2euhrI |title=Mining Queens Gina Rinehart, Angela Bennett in Legal Battle Over Hope Downs Iron Ore Mine |work=[[International Business Times]] |date=27 September 2012 }}{{cite news |author=Marks, Kathy |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/australasia/richest-women-in-australia-go-to-war-over-mining-rights-8182554.html |title=Richest women in Australia go to war over mining rights |work=[[The Independent]] |date=28 September 2012 }} ==Biography== Her late father, Peter Wright, co-founded Wright Prospecting. Her late brother was [[Michael Wright (Australian businessman)|Michael Wright]] (1937-2012), the owner of the [[Voyager Estate]] winery in [[Margaret River, Western Australia|Margaret River]]. She heads Wright Prospecting. In 2010, she and her brother received {{AUD}}1 billion from Gina Rinehart after she was legally forced to give up twenty-five per cent in the [[Rhodes Ridges]] iron ore mine 60 km west of [[Newman, Western Australia|Newman]] in the [[Pilbara]]. She owns fifteen per cent of [[Pilbara Iron|Hamersley Iron]] shares from the [[Rio Tinto Group]], Gina Rinehart owning the other fifty per cent. In September 2012, she sued Rinehart to recover fifty per cent of 4, 5 and 6 tenements of the [[Hope Downs mine]], named after Gina Rinehart's late mother, [[Hope Hancock]].{{cite news |author1=Garvey, Paul |author2=Burrell, Andrew |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/battle-of-the-billionaire-iron-ladies-as-hope-downs-court-case-looms/story-e6frg8zx-1226482147576 |title=Battle of the billionaire iron ladies as Hope Downs court case looms |work=The Australian |date=27 September 2012 }} ==Personal life== She is married, and has seven children. She is the second richest woman in Australia, after [[Gina Rinehart]]. In 2014, the ''[[Business Review Weekly]]'' assessed Bennett's [[net worth]] at {{AUD}}1.55 billion.{{cite journal |url=http://www.brw.com.au/p/lists/rich-200/2014/brw_rich_list_angela_bennett_ihK6iGPCJ2EUi0OmjzlYvI |title=BRW Rich 200 list 2014: 22. Angela Bennett |journal=[[Business Review Weekly|BRW]] |date=27 June 2014 |accessdate=29 June 2014 |location=Sydney }} In September 2009, she sold her mansion in the [[Mosman Park, Western Australia|Mosman Park]] neighbourhood of Perth for {{AUD}}57.5 million and downsized to a {{AUD}}8 million apartment in [[Fremantle, Western Australia|Fremantle]].{{cite news |author=Sonti, Chalpat |url=http://www.smh.com.au/business/property/perth-mansion-sold-for-australian-record-of-575m-20091208-khcg.html |title=Perth mansion sold for Australian record of $57.5m |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=8 September 2009 }}{{cite news |author=Keila, Jon |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/legal-battle-over-20m-super-yacht/story-e6frf7l6-1225965716510 |title=Legal battle over $20m super yacht |work=[[Herald Sun]] |date=5 December 2010 }} In 2010, she sold her {{AUD}}20 million yacht. Her son, Todd Bennett, was appointed to the Board of Directors of Apex Mineral in 2008, but he no longer sits on it as of 2012.{{cite news |author=Gosch, Elizabeth |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/mining-energy/apex-reckons-it-has-struck-gold/story-e6frg9df-1111116955114 |title=Apex reckons it has struck gold with Bennett posting |work=[[The Australian]] |date=19 July 2008 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.apexminerals.com/corporate_directors.php |publisher=Apex Minerals |title=Board of Directors }} He also sat on the Board of the Finance and Energy Exchange. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bennett, Angela}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Perth, Western Australia]] [[Category:Australian businesspeople]] [[Category:Australian billionaires]] [[Category:Australian women in business]] [[Category:1940s births]]

revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=August 2013}} {{cleanup|date=January 2011}} In 1904, '''Benjamin Ginsberg''', a Russian immigrant and pioneer in the [[Cederberg]] region of the Cape, [[South Africa]], became the first to trade [[Rooibos]] (''Red Bush'') tea and cultivate it under production.
The [[Bushmen]], who lived in the area, first discovered that the fine, needle-like leaves of the "[[Aspalathus Linearis]]" plant made a distinctive, aromatic tea. For centuries, they had harvested the wild-growing plants, chopped them with axes and then bruised them with hammers, leaving them to ferment in heaps before drying them in the sun. In 1904, Benjamin Ginsberg started trading the tea from the [[Bushmen]], distributing and marketing it throughout the Cape. Ginsberg was descended from a family that had been in the tea industry in Europe for centuries and this provided him with the necessary experience to market the tea successfully. Although a direct heir to the three family baronies, Ginsberg refrained from using his title.
By the late 1920s, growing demand for the tea led to problems with supply of the wild Red Bush plants. Working with his friend, a local [[General Practitioner|GP]] and keen [[botanist]], Ginsberg used innovative germination techniques to cultivate the tea under production.
After Benjamin's death in 1944, his son Charles took over the business, introducing sophisticated machinery to cut the unusual leaves and building large “courts” on his farms in which to dry and cure the tea under the hot [[Cederberg]] sun. He was soon supplying tea seed to hundreds of farmers and promoting his Eleven O' Clock brand and its healthful properties (e.g. [[caffeine]]-free) across a variety of channels, including cinema advertising, which was still new to [[South Africa]]. Charles began distributing internationally and, although he sold the business in the 1970s, the brand is still widely distributed and the distinctive 1940's Eleven O' Clock packaging, depicting a mother and daughter serving tea, remains almost unchanged.
In the 1990s, spurred on by greater consumer awareness of different teas, brand diversity and mainstream distribution (particularly through supermarkets), international demand for Red Bush tea increased dramatically.
==References== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101124070552/http://cphpost.dk/news/community/93-community/47309-south-african-rooibos-morning-tea.html South African Rooibos morning tea] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110708114207/http://www.cancerdecisions.com/content/view/479/72/lang%2Cenglish/ The Rooibos Cantata; Building the Immune System]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ginsberg, Benjamin}} [[Category:South African businesspeople]] [[Category:1944 deaths]] [[Category:Year of birth missing]]

revision.text:
The '''Brazilian Institute of Actuaries''' ({{lang-pt|Instituto Brasileiro de Atuária, IBA}}) is the national association for [[actuary|actuaries]] in [[Brazil]].
==History== The Brazilian Institute of Actuaries was founded in 1944, by mathematicians and researchers interested in extending their field of study to subjects related to [[actuarial science]]. Established in Rio de Janeiro, the IBA’s main objective is to promote and support research and development initiatives, aiming at improving the scientific study of contingent facts of an economic, financial or biometric nature, in all their aspects and applications.
==Role== The Institute is the only entity representing the actuarial profession in Brazil, and for this reason it has concentrated efforts towards becoming a formal [[regulatory body]]. This new status would render it more capable to employ the adequate means to address professional issues in this area.
Professional actuaries are required by the Brazilian legislation to register with the National Labor Department prior to their employment in the Brazilian market and, although the IBA has not been assigned any formal responsibility by the government, it plays an important part in this regulation by assuring professional ethics and good practice among professionals. The National Labor Department requires professional actuaries to present one of following documents for registration: Bachelor’s degree in actuarial science, duly recognized and registered with the National Department of Education or Bachelor’s degree in actuarial science from a recognized foreign institution and accepted by the National Department of Education.
In 2002, the [[International Actuarial Association]] (IAA) defined a minimum standard syllabus for Actuarial Science courses, with which all affiliated actuarial associations will be required to comply by 2005. With this purpose, and as a member of the IAA, the IBA is committed to implement a certification process using exams to which new applicants would have to be submitted, following a trend already consolidated not only in the United States, but also in Canada and in certain European countries.
As of 2002, the Institute has registered more than 600 members, including individuals and legal entities providing actuarial services, as well as pension funds, capitalization entities and insurance companies. Members are admitted to one of six membership categories after approval by decision of either the Institute’s Board of Directors or the Plenary of Members.
==Membership== IBA Membership Categories * Junior Members: students from a recognized graduation course in actuarial science, formally accepted by IBA’s Board of Directors; * Individual Members: actuaries with a Bachelor’s Degree obtained from an accredited Brazilian or foreign institution, admitted by IBA’s Board of Directors; * Organizations: private companies and public entities officially accepted by IBA’s Board of Directors; * Honorary: individuals granted this position by the Plenary of Members as recognition of the value of their work, scientific knowledge or experience in areas related to the objectives pursued by the IBA; * Meritorious: individuals and legal entities considered by the Plenary of Members to deserve public recognition from the IBA as a result of their legacy, relevant services or donations. * Correspondents: Brazilian or non-Brazilian residents accepted by the Board of Directors due to their interest in the Institute’s activities or to their contribution to the IBA.
==Organization== The Board of Directors holds monthly meetings to discuss and decide upon issues relevant to the Institute’s interests. Many of the positions assumed by the Board of Directors are based on previous studies carried out by the various existing commissions, which centralize discussions in specific areas such as Pension Funds, General Insurance, Health Insurance, Capitalization Plans, Education, Foreign Relations and Planning of Events.
In every month of September a general meeting is held in order to revise and ratify the Institute’s Annual Report, Statements of Accounts and their corresponding Audit reports. This assembly also votes to choose the members to compose the following year’s Audit Committee. Every two years, this General Board Meeting also elects the President, the Vice-President and the Board of Directors for the following two-year term.
The IBA maintains a newsletter focusing on topics of actuarial interests: ATUAR. Published bimonthly in Portuguese since January 1996, it has proved to be an efficient channel of communication with associates, bringing news from the Brazilian actuarial market and interviews, as well as book reviews and suggestions of relevant websites and news features. Just visit www.atuarios.org.br to access the web version of ATUAR and to find out more about the IBA.
==External links==
* [http://www.atuarios.org.br Brazilian Institute of Actuaries official website]
[[Category:Actuarial associations]] [[Category:Business organisations based in Brazil]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1944]] [[Category:1944 establishments in Brazil]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{advert|date=October 2014}} {{notability|companies|date=October 2014}} }}
{{Infobox company | name = Breton S.p.A. | logo = Breton company logo.jpg | caption = | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | foundation = [[Castello di Godego]], [[Italy]] ({{Start date|1963}}) | founder = Marcello Toncelli | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | location_city = [[Castello di Godego]] | location_country = [[Italy]] | area_served = Worldwide | industry = [[Manufacturing]] | products = * plants for producing composite stone * machines for processing natural stone * machines for processing ceramic materials * cnc machining centres for high-speed machining | homepage = {{URL|breton.it}} | footnotes = | intl = }}
'''Breton S.p.A.''' is an Italian privately held company established in 1963.<ref>{{cite web|title=Company profile Breton S.p.a.|url=http://www.hoovers.com/company-information/cs/company-profile.BRETON_SPA.e3d259c464432a6a.html|website=www.hoovers.com/|publisher=Hoovers a D&B Company|accessdate=14 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Company overview of Breton S.p.A.|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=1708551|website=investing.businessweek.com/|publisher=BusinessWeek.com|accessdate=14 July 2014}}</ref> The company produces machines and plants for [[engineered stone]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Stone Equipment|url=http://www.dmoz.org/Business/Construction_and_Maintenance/Materials_and_Supplies/Masonry_and_Stone/Natural_Stone/Equipment/|website=www.dmoz.org/|accessdate=14 July 2014}}</ref> and [[metalworking]]. Machines and plants by Breton can be used in diverse sectors such as die-making, aerospace, automotive, racing cars, energy, gears, general mechanics, stone processing and kitchen top manufacturing.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Impelluso|first1=Thomas J.|title=Italian machines that make machines|url=http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2010/Apr/21/italian-machines-that-make-machines/?#article-copy|website=www.utsandiego.com/|publisher=The San Diego Union-Tribune|accessdate=14 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Impelluso|first1=Thomas J.|title=Italian Machines That Make Machines|url=http://mechanical.sdsu.edu/sdsu_newscenter/news.aspx?s=72126|website=mechanical.sdsu.edu/|publisher=San Diego State University - NewsCenter|accessdate=14 July 2014}}</ref>
== History ==
Breton was established in 1963 in [[Castello di Godego]], Italy, by Marcello Toncelli,<ref>{{cite web|title=Marcello Toncelli Biography|url=http://www.blurb.com/b/534441-marcello-toncelli|accessdate=14 July 2014}}</ref> who started developing new technologies and manufacturing industrial plants for producing engineered stone.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Moriarty|first1=Ann Marie|title=Diamonds Are Forever. These Counters May Be Too.|url=http://countintel.com/pdf/Diamonds_Are_Forever.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060509044734/http://www.countintel.com/pdf/Diamonds_Are_Forever.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=9 May 2006|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=14 July 2014}}</ref> Marcello Toncelli invented the [[Bretonstone]] technology, also known as vibrocompression under vacuum, a patented technology <ref>{{cite web|title=Process for the manufacturing of slabs or blocks of conglomerate of stone granulate and polyester resin|url=http://patents.justia.com/patent/20090253829|website=patents.justia.com/|publisher=Justia Patents|accessdate=14 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=United States Patent No. US8,030,441 B2|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=patentimages.storage.googleapis.com/pdfs/US8030441.pdf|publisher=Google.com|accessdate=28 February 2014}}</ref> which is used today by most engineered stone manufacturers.<ref name="manufacturers">[http://isfanow.org/quartz-2/ Technology used by most leading engineered stone manufacturers - according to International Surface Fabricators Association] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140408065826/http://isfanow.org/quartz-2/ |date=April 8, 2014 }}</ref> Around the mid 1990s the company decided to enter also into the [[machine tool]] market, manufacturing machining centres for the mechanical industry.
In 2003 Marcello Toncelli, Breton's founder, died, and the control of the company passed to his sons Luca and Dario Toncelli, who since then have been running the company together with the founder's long-time partner, Roberto Chiavacci, Vice President of the Board of Directors.
In 2011 the company acquired Bideseimpianti and signed a partnership with Boart & Wire, diamond wires manufacturer.<ref>{{cite web|title=Newsline: Technology supplier Breton of Italy acquires Bideseimpianti|url=http://www.stoneworld.com/articles/86754-newsline-technology-supplier-breton-of-italy-acquires-bideseimpianti|website=www.stoneworld.com/|publisher=Stone World.com|accessdate=14 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Breton Acquires Wire-Saw Maker Bideseimpiani|url=http://www.stoneupdate.com/news-info/latest-stuff/67-breton-acquires-wire-saw-maker-bideseimpiani|website=www.stoneupdate.com/|publisher=Stone update|accessdate=14 July 2014}}</ref> In 2014 Breton became an official member of the Graphene Flagship Project, one of the largest research initiative of the European Commission<ref>{{cite web|title=Commission announces huge new influx of partners to the Graphene Flagship project|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-14-707_en.htm|website=europa.eu/|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=14 July 2014}}</ref> which focuses on the [[potential applications of graphene]].
== Products ==
Breton manufactures machines and technology for following fields: * engineered stone processing * natural stone processing<ref>{{cite web|title=Machinery : Breton Shapemill NCF|url=http://www.naturalstonespecialist.com/currentissue/unlockednewsarticle.php?id=4524|website=www.naturalstonespecialist.com/|publisher=Natural Stone Specialist|accessdate=14 July 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403105050/http://www.naturalstonespecialist.com/currentissue/unlockednewsarticle.php?id=4524|archivedate=3 April 2015|df=}}</ref> * ceramic materials processing * high-speed machining for aerospace, formula 1, automotive and die-mould sector
== Awards ==
* Windows Embedded Partner Excellence Award Breton's solution to connect through the cloud to manage tele-service for 4,000 machines for hundreds of customers worldwide has been awarded in 2012 by [[Microsoft]] with the Windows Embedded Partner Excellence Award for manufacturing.<ref>{{cite web|last=Javnozon|first=Dan|title=Microsoft Honors Winners of the Windows Embedded Partner Excellence Awards|url=http://blogs.msdn.com/b/windows-embedded/archive/2013/01/02/microsoft-honors-winners-of-the-windows-embedded-partner-excellence-awards.aspx|publisher=Msdn.com|accessdate=28 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Custom Manufacturer of Stone Products Improves Productivity by 30 Percent|url=http://www.microsoft.com/casestudies/Windows-Embedded-Standard-7/Lido-Stone-Works/Custom-Manufacturer-of-Stone-Products-Improves-Productivity-by-30-Percent/710000002834|publisher=Microsoft.com|accessdate=13 April 2014}}</ref>
== Footnotes ==
{{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.breton.it Company's official website] * [http://www.bretonstory.com Timeline of Breton's history]

A '''buyout clause''' or '''release clause''' refers to a clause in a [[contract]] that imposes an obligation on another organisation wishing to acquire the services of the employee under contract to pay the (usually substantial) fee of the clause to the organisation which issued the contract and 'owns' the employee.
It is most commonly used in reference to sports teams, where a [[Transfer (association football)|transfer fee]] is usually paid for a player under contract; however, the current owning club is not obliged to sell their player, and if an agreement on a suitable fee cannot be reached, the buying club can instead resort to paying the player's buyout fee – should their contract have such a clause – which the owning club cannot block.<ref name=applied>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/spanish-primera-division/15/blog/post/3172294/how-release-clauses-work-neymar-treated-like-any-spanish-worker|title=How release clauses are applied: Neymar like 'any other worker' in Spain|date=5 August 2017|publisher=[[ESPN]]|accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref> Usually this is a higher amount than the player's expected market value, although on occasion a player at a smaller club will sign a contract but insist on a low buyout fee to attract bigger clubs if their performances generate interest.
The aim of this clause is twofold; firstly with its high amount, competing teams are discouraged from attempting to acquire the player if the current club shows no signs of selling them, and secondly it raises any hint to the players not to go through with their contractual commitment.
[[Football in Spain|In Spain]], buyout clauses have been mandatory in football contracts since 1985. If wishing to rescind their contract, the players are required to pay the buyout fee to their current club personally (via the [[Liga de Fútbol Profesional|league body]]), which would be advanced to them by the club signing them;<ref name=applied/><ref name=change/><ref name=vanguard/> however this advance of funds was originally deemed by the Spanish government to be taxable income, requiring the buying club to pay [[income tax]] on top of the fee itself, with the prohibitively high costs involved in this dual transaction discouraging clubs from making such deals.<ref name=change>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cityam.com/252013/recent-change-spains-tax-laws-could-make-buying-liga-manchester-united|title=A change in Spain's tax laws could make buying La Liga players easier for Premier League clubs such as Manchester United|date=22 October 2016|work=[[City A.M.]]|accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref><ref name=vanguard>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vanguardngr.com/2017/08/spanish-buyout-clauses-work/|title=How Spanish buyout clauses work|date=2 August 2017|publisher=[[Vanguard (Nigeria)|Vanguard]]|accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref> In October 2016 the laws were changed, with the buyout fee advances to the players no longer subject to tax, meaning only the fee itself had to be paid.<ref name=change/><ref name=vanguard/>
As of November 2017, the five largest buyout clauses were those of association football players [[Cristiano Ronaldo]] and player [[Karim Benzema]] of [[Real Madrid]] (€1 billion each) – Ronaldo subsequently moved to [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] (a deal not involving the buyout fee); [[Isco]] and [[Marco Asensio]] (also Real Madrid, €700 million each),<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.eurosport.com/football/liga/2017-2018/isco-pens-new-real-madrid-deal-with-huge-buyout-cause-marcelo-also-extends-contract_sto6333555/story.shtml|title=Isco pens new Real Madrid deal with huge buyout clause, Marcelo also extends contract|date=2017-09-14|work=[[Eurosport]]|access-date=2017-09-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/football/4223054/isco-signs-new-five-year-real-madrid-deal-and-his-staggering-release-clause-will-leave-you-speechless/|title=Real Madrid midfielder signs new five-year-deal with outrageous buyout clause|date=2017-08-11|work=The Sun|access-date=2017-08-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/the-neymar-effect-real-madrid-slap-astronomical-buyout/zd8ndsturtlw1jcarttg0zunc|title=The Neymar effect: Real Madrid slap astronomical buyout clauses on stars to avoid Barcelona’s fate|website=[[Goal (website)|Goal]]|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2017-2018/video-lionel-messi-signs-new-contract-fc-barcelona|title=Lionel Messi signs new deal through 2020/21 season {{!}} FC Barcelona|website=FC Barcelona|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-25}}</ref> and that of [[FC Barcelona]] player [[Lionel Messi]] (also €700 million).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/42123022|title=Lionel Messi: Barcelona forward signs new deal until 2021|date=2017-11-25|work=[[BBC Sport]]|access-date=2017-11-25}}</ref>
On 3 August 2017, [[Paris Saint-Germain]] activated the buyout clause of Brazilian footballer [[Neymar]] from FC Barcelona, which was set at €222 million, making him the [[world football transfer record|most expensive football player]] in history,<ref>{{cite web|title=Neymar Has Signed a Record-Breaking $262 Million Deal With PSG|url=http://time.com/4887096/neymar-psg-world-record-transfer//|website=The Time|date=4 August 2017|access-date=4 August 2017}}</ref><ref name=applied/> ahead of the previous record set by [[Paul Pogba]] (€105 million) in 2016.
== References == {{Reflist}}

[[Cessna Citation Longitude|Citation Longitude]]
[[Cessna Citation Hemisphere|Citation Hemisphere]] }} |} The '''Cessna Citation family''' is [[Cessna]]'s [[business jet]]s line. The 7,000th Citation was delivered on June 27, 2016, forming the largest business jet fleet: the first Citation was put into service in 1972 and more than 35 million flight hours have been logged since.{{cite press release |url= http://txtav.com/en/newsroom/2016/06/cessna-delivers-milestone-7000th-citation-as-netjets-first-citation-latitude |title= Cessna delivers milestone 7,000th Citation as NetJets’ first Citation Latitude |date= June 27, 2016 |publisher= [[Textron Aviation]]}} It started with the small [[Cessna Citation I|Citation I]] prototype flying on September 15, 1969 and produced until 1985, developed into the 1978-2006 [[Cessna Citation II|Citation II]]/Bravo, the 1989-2011 [[Cessna Citation V|Citation V]]/Ultra/Encore and the [[Cessna CitationJet|CitationJet]] since 1993. The standup [[Cessna Citation III|Citation III]]/VI/VII was delivered from 1983 to 2000, its fuselage was reused in the [[Cessna Citation X|Citation X]]/X+ delivered from 1996 to 2018, the [[Citation Excel|Excel]] since 1998 and the [[Citation Sovereign|Sovereign]] since 2004. The [[Citation Mustang|Mustang]] was a [[Very Light Jet]] delivered from 2006 to 2017 while the flat floor fuselage [[Citation Latitude|Latitude]] is delivered since 2015 and the larger [[Citation Longitude|Longitude]] from 2018. ==Lineage== {|class="navbox collapsible" !colspan=66 class="navbox-title"|{{navbar-collapsible| Citation deliveries timeline }} |- style="background-color:WhiteSmoke;" |colspan=10|   = Latitude cross section |} ==Models== ===Citation I=== [[File:CN Air Cessna 501 Citation I SP (cropped).jpg|thumb|Model 500 Citation I]] The small '''[[Cessna Citation I|Citation I]]''' (500) was announced in October 1968, its ''Fanjet 500'' prototype first flew on September 15, 1969 and it was certified as the ''Citation'' on September 9, 1971. It was upgraded in 1976 as the ''Citation I'' and a single pilot variant, production ended in 1985 after 689 deliveries. Powered by [[JT15D]] turbofans, the [[straight wing]] aircraft was developed into the [[Cessna Citation II|Citation II]]/Bravo. ===Citation II/Bravo=== [[File:LUCAS OIL PRODUCTS INC DBA CROSS TIMBERS, MO - 2000 CESSNA 550 N48FW (550-0948) (5137861075) (cropped).jpg|thumb|model 550 Citation II]] The '''[[Cessna Citation II|Citation II]]''', a stretched [[Citation I]], was announced in September 1976, first flew on January 31, 1977 and was certified in March 1978. The ''II/SP'' is a single pilot version, the improved ''S/II'' first flew on February 14, 1984 and the ''Citation Bravo'' upgraded with new avionics and [[Pratt & Whitney Canada PW500|P&WC PW530]]A turbofans on April 25, 1995, while the [[United States]] used it as the ''T-47''. Production ceased in 2006 after {{#expr:688+336+160}} were delivered. === Citation III/VI/VII === [[File:Cessna 650 Citation III, Wheels Aviation AN1469360 (cropped).jpg|thumb|Model 650 Citation III]] The {{cvt|2350|nmi|km}} range '''[[Citation III]]''' (Model 650) was announced at the October 1976 [[National Business Aviation Association|NBAA]] convention, it made its [[maiden flight]] on May 30, 1979, received its [[type certification]] on April 30, 1982 and was delivered between 1983 and 1992. The cheaper '''Citation VI''' was produced from 1991 to 1995 and the more powerful '''Citation VII''' was offered between 1992 and 2000, 360 of all variants were delivered. An all new design, it had a 312 sq ft (29 m²) [[swept wing]] for a 22,000 lb (10 t) MTOW, a [[T-tail]] and two {{cvt|3650-4080|lbf|kN}} [[TFE731]] turbofans. Its fuselage cross section and cockpit were kept in the later [[Citation X]], [[Citation Excel]] and [[Citation Sovereign]]. ===Citation V/Ultra/Encore=== [[File:N217TH 1996 CESSNA 560 560-0390 (5045025416) (cropped).jpg|thumb|Model 560 Citation V]] Stretched from the [[Cessna Citation II|Citation II]], the '''[[Cessna Citation V|Citation V]]''' (Model 560) prototype flew in August 1987, it was certified on December 9, 1988 and delivered from April 1987, {{#expr:262+279+168+65}} were delivered until 2011. The upgraded ''Citation Ultra'' was announced in September 1993, the ''Citation Encore'' upgraded with [[Pratt & Whitney Canada PW500|PW535]] turbofans was announced in 1998, before the improved ''Encore+''. Its US Military designation is ''UC-35''. ===CitationJet=== [[File:OO-FLN (cropped).JPG|thumb|Model 525A CitationJet CJ2]] The '''[[Cessna CitationJet]]''' was launched in October 1989, its first flight was on April 29, 1991, FAA certification was awarded on October 16, 1992, first delivery happened on March 30, 1993, and by June 2017, 2,000 of all variants have been delivered. Powered by two {{cvt|1900|lbf|kN}} [[Williams FJ44]]s, it uses the [[Cessna Citation II|Citation II]]'s forward fuselage with a new carry-through section, straight wing, and [[T-tail]]. The basic model was updated with the '''CJ/CJ1/M2''' (525) names, it was stretched in the '''CJ2/CJ2+''' (525A) delivered since 2000, then further in the '''CJ3/CJ3+''' (525B) delivered from December 2004 and finally in the '''CJ4''' (525C) delivered since 2010. The '''[[Cessna 526 CitationJet]]''' is a twin-seat tandem military trainer developed from the CitationJet for the [[Joint Primary Aircraft Training System|JPATS]] competition.{{cite book |last=Taylor |first= Michael J. H.|authorlink= |coauthors= |title= Brassey's World Aircraft & Systems Directory|year=1996 |publisher= Brassey's |location=London |isbn=1-85753-198-1|page=128}} ===Citation X/X+=== [[File:N975QS 2002 Cessna 750 C-N 750-0175 Citation X (7039507775) (cropped).jpg|thumb|Model 750 Citation X]] The '''[[Citation X]]{{efn|''X'' as in the Roman numeral for ''ten''}}''' (Model 750) was announced at the October 1990 [[National Business Aviation Association|NBAA]] convention, it made its [[maiden flight]] on December 21, 1993, received its [[type certification]] on June 3, 1996 and was first delivered in July 1996. The updated '''Citation X+''' was offered from 2012 with a {{cvt|14|inch}} cabin stretch and upgraded systems. Keeping the [[Cessna Citation III|Citation III]] fuselage cross section, it has a new 37° [[swept wing]] with an area of 527 ft² (49 m²) for a fast Mach 0.935 [[V Speeds|MMo]] and a 36,600 lb (16.6 t) MTOW, a T-tail and two 7,034 lbf (31.29 kN) [[AE3007]] turbofans for 3,460 nmi (6,408 km) of range. After 338 deliveries, production should end in 2018. ===Excel/XLS/XLS+=== [[File:Cessna 560XL Citation XLS (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|Model 560XL Citation Excel]] The {{cvt|2,100|nmi|km}} [[Citation Excel]] (Model 560XL) was announced in October 1994, it first flew on February 29, 1996, certification was granted in April 1998 and over 900 have been delivered. The 20,200 lb (9,200 kg) MTOW jet is powered by two {{cvt|3650-4080|lbf|kN}} [[Pratt & Whitney Canada PW500|PW500]] turbofans, has the [[Citation V]] (560) [[cruciform tail]] and unswept [[supercritical wing]] of 370 sq ft (34 m²), and the [[Citation X]] stand-up cabin slightly shortened. The '''XLS''' 2004 update has upgraded engines and a [[glass cockpit]] and the 2008 '''XLS+''' has [[FADEC]] and a revised nose. ===Sovereign=== [[File:Cessna Citation Sovereign Rafael Luiz (14725958464) (cropped).jpg|thumb|Model 680 Citation Sovereign]] The {{cvt|3,200|nmi|km}} range '''[[Citation Sovereign]]''' (Model 680) was announced at the 1998 [[National Business Aviation Association|NBAA]] convention, it made its [[maiden flight]] in February [[2002 in aviation|2002]], certification was awarded on June 2, 2004, and deliveries began in late September. The improved '''Sovereign+''' was announced at the October 2012 NBAA for a first flight in April 2012 and deliveries in December, with [[winglets]], improved engines and flight deck. The [[Citation Excel]] fuselage was stretched and joined with a large, clean-sheet 16.3 °, {{cvt|516|sqft}} wing and two {{cvt|5,900|lbf|kN}} [[PW300]] engines for a {{cvt|30,800|lb}} [[max takeoff weight|MTOW]]. ===Mustang=== [[File:Cessna 510 Citation Mustang AN1613988 (cropped).jpg|thumb|Model 510 Citation Mustang]] The '''[[Cessna Citation Mustang]]''' (Model 510) is a [[very light jet]] launched at the 2002 [[National Business Aviation Association|NBAA]] convention, it first flew on 23 April 2005. It received its FAA [[type certification]] September 8, 2006, was first delivered on November 22 and production ended in 2017 after 479 aircraft were built. The {{cvt|8645|lb}} [[MTOW]] jet is powered by two {{cvt|1460|lbf|kN}} [[Pratt & Whitney Canada PW615F|P&WC PW615F]] [[turbofan]]s, can reach {{cvt|340|knots|km/h}} and can cover {{cvt|1,167|nmi|km}}. ===Columbus=== The '''[[Cessna Citation Columbus|Citation Columbus]]''' (Model 850) was a 4000 nmi range business jet project launched in February 2008 and cancelled in July 2009, topping the Citation family. Powered by 8,830 lbf (39.3 kN) [[Pratt & Whitney Canada PW800|PW810]] turbofans, the $27 million aircraft had a 709 sq ft (66 m²), 30° swept airfoil. ===Latitude=== [[File:Air Charter Scotland, G-SHUI, Cessna 680A Citation Latitude (44389250211) (cropped).jpg|thumb|Model 680A Citation Latitude]] The {{cvt|2700|nmi|km}} range '''[[Cessna Citation Latitude|Citation Latitude]]''' (Model 680A) was announced at the 2011 [[National Business Aviation Association|NBAA]] convention, the prototype first flew on 18 February 2014, it achieved FAA certification on June 5, 2015 and first deliveries begun on August 27. It keeps the [[Cessna Citation Sovereign|Model 680 Sovereign]] wing, twin [[Pratt & Whitney Canada PW300|P&WC PW306D]] turbofans and [[cruciform tail]], but its clean sheet stand-up circular [[fuselage]] has a flat floor. This new fuselage is kept in the later [[Cessna Citation Longitude]]. ===Longitude=== [[File:EBACE 2018, Le Grand-Saconnex (BL7C0443) (longitude) (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Model 700 Longitude mockup]] The {{cvt|3,500|nmi|km}} range '''[[Cessna Citation Longitude|Citation Longitude]]''' (Model 700) was announced at the May 2012 [[EBACE]], it made its first flight on October 8, 2016, certification is expected in the third quarter of 2018 with deliveries later in the same year. Powered by [[Honeywell HTF7000]] turbofans, The aluminum [[airframe]] has the fuselage cross-section of the [[Cessna Citation Latitude|Citation Latitude]], stretched by a seat row, with a new ~28° [[swept wing]] and a [[T-tail]]. ===Hemisphere=== [[File:EBACE 2018, Le Grand-Saconnex (BL7C0443) (hemisphere) (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Citation Hemisphere Model]] The '''[[Cessna Citation Hemisphere|Citation Hemisphere]]''' is a {{convert|4500|nmi|km}} range, Mach 0.9 business jet project. Announced in November 2015, it was then expected to fly in 2019 but its development was suspended in April 2018 to wait for its [[Safran Silvercrest]] engines to be perfected. == Current Models == {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Model ! Length !! Span !! Area ! Sweep !! Inside !! Pax. ! MTOW !! Cruise !! Range ! Engines !! revision.comment: US AID is a different thing and may cause confusion
revision.text:
'''Chi-square automatic interaction detection''' ('''CHAID''') is a [[Decision tree learning|decision tree]] technique, based on adjusted significance testing ([[Bonferroni testing]]). The technique was developed in South Africa and was published in 1980 by Gordon V. Kass, who had completed a PhD thesis on this topic. CHAID can be used for prediction (in a similar fashion to [[regression analysis]], this version of CHAID being originally known as XAID) as well as classification, and for detection of interaction between variables. CHAID is based on a formal extension of the United States' AID (Automatic Interaction Detection) and THAID (THeta Automatic Interaction Detection) procedures of the 1960s and 1970s, which in turn were extensions of earlier research, including that performed in the UK in the 1950s.
In practice, CHAID is often used in the context of [[direct marketing]] to select groups of consumers and predict how their responses to some variables affect other variables, although other early applications were in the field of medical and psychiatric research.
Like other decision trees, CHAID's advantages are that its output is highly visual and easy to interpret. Because it uses multiway splits by default, it needs rather large sample sizes to work effectively, since with small sample sizes the respondent groups can quickly become too small for reliable analysis.
One important advantage of CHAID over alternatives such as multiple regression is that it is non-parametric.
== See also == *[[Chi-squared distribution]] *[[Latent class model]] *[[Structural equation modeling]] *[[Market segment]] *[[Decision tree learning]] *[[Multiple comparisons]]
{{No footnotes|date=July 2010}}
== References == {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Belson, William A.; ''Matching and prediction on the principle of biological classification'', Applied Statistics, Vol. 8 (1959), pp. 65–75 * Morgan, John A.; & Sonquist, James N.; ''Problems in the analysis of survey data and a proposal'', [[Journal of the American Statistical Association]], Vol. 58 (1963), pp. 415–434 * Press, Laurence I.; Rogers, Miles S.; & Shure, Gerald H.; ''An interactive technique for the analysis of multivariate data'', Behavioral Science, Vol. 14 (1969), pp. 364–370 * Kass, Gordon V.; ''An Exploratory Technique for Investigating Large Quantities of Categorical Data'', Applied Statistics, Vol. 29, No. 2 (1980), pp. 119–127 * Hawkins, Douglas M. ; and Kass, Gordon V.; ''Automatic Interaction Detection'', in Hawkins, Douglas M. (ed), ''Topics in Applied Multivariate Analysis'', Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1982, pp. 269–302 * Hooton, Thomas M.; Haley, Robert W.; Culver, David H.; White, John W.; Morgan, W. Meade; & Carroll, Raymond J.; ''The Joint Associations of Multiple Risk Factors with the Occurrence of Nosocomial Infections'', American Journal of Medicine, Vol. 70, (1981), pp. 960–970 * Brink, Susanne; & Van Schalkwyk, Dirk J.; ''Serum ferritin and mean corpuscular volume as predictors of bone marrow iron stores'', South African Medical Journal, Vol. 61, (1982), pp. 432–434 * McKenzie, Dean P.; McGorry, Patrick D.; Wallace, Chris S.; Low, Lee H.; Copolov, David L.; & Singh, Bruce S.; ''Constructing a Minimal Diagnostic Decision Tree'', Methods of Information in Medicine, Vol. 32 (1993), pp. 161–166 * Magidson, Jay; ''The CHAID approach to segmentation modeling: chi-squared automatic interaction detection'', in Bagozzi, Richard P. (ed); ''Advanced Methods of Marketing Research'', Blackwell, Oxford, GB, 1994, pp. 118–159 * Hawkins, Douglas M.; Young, S. S.; & Rosinko, A.; ''Analysis of a large structure-activity dataset using recursive partitioning'', Quantitative Structure-Activity Relationships, Vol. 16, (1997), pp. 296–302
==Sources== * Luchman, J.N.; ''CHAID: Stata module to conduct chi-square automated interaction detection'', Available for free [https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s457752.html download], or type within Stata: ssc install chaid. * Luchman, J.N.; ''CHAIDFOREST: Stata module to conduct random forest ensemble classification based on chi-square automated interaction detection (CHAID) as base learner'', Available for free [https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s457932.html download], or type within Stata: ssc install chaidforest.

revision.text:
The '''Credit Managers' Index''' '''(CMI)''' is a monthly economic indicator of financial activity reflecting credit managers' responses to levels of favorable and unfavorable factors. The measure has been sourced in stories from publications such as the ''Wall Street Journal'', ''CFO'' and ''Bloomberg''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ww2.cfo.com/credit/2015/09/credit-managers-index-continues-decline/|title=Credit Managers' Index Continues to Decline -|last=Kuehner-Hebert|first=Katie|date=2015-09-30|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2012-11-01/economy-looking-up-ahead-of-big-jobs-number|title=Economy Looking Up Ahead of Big Jobs Number|last=Coy|first=Peter|website=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2016-06-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/economics/2007/10/01/woes-dont-extend-to-credit-managers/|title=Woes Don’t Extend to Credit Managers|last=WSJ|access-date=2016-06-30}}</ref>
Tracked since February 2002, the CMI is produced by the [[National Association of Credit Management]] (NACM)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nacm.org/cmi.html|title=Credit Managers' Index (CMI)|website=nacm.org|access-date=2016-06-30}}</ref> and is currently conducted by Armada Corporate Intelligence's Chris Kuehl, who also serves as NACM's economic advisor. The CMI is compiled through a voluntary poll of credit and finance professionals in the service and manufacturing sectors. The CMI results generally are released on the last business day of each month.<ref>http://web.nacm.org/CMI/PDF/CMIcurrent.pdf</ref>
A CMI number of more than 50 indicates an economy in expansion; less than 50 indicates contraction.
Unlike many economic indexes, the CMI resisted the month-to-month swings during the most recent{{when?|date=October 2017}} economic downturn. The index accurately signaled that the economic plunge was stabilizing and beginning to recover from the recession.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nacmnc.org/news/news.asp?id=271241|title=Simple Act, Huge Impact - NACM North Central|website=www.nacmnc.org|access-date=2017-11-28}}</ref>
The Chartered Institute of Credit Management (CICM) in the UK produces a similar Index<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cicm.com/credit-management-index/|title=CICM UK Credit Management Index - Chartered Institute of Credit Management|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-30}}</ref> on a quarterly basis reflecting its members' responses to questions about the same factors and it uses the same methodology.
==Methodology== The index is based on survey responses of approximately 1,000 trade credit managers in the second half of each month. There is typically an approximately equal representation between the manufacturing and service sectors. Respondents from throughout the United States are asked to comment on whether they are seeing improvement, deterioration, or no change for various favorable and unfavorable factors.
The computation of seasonality is based on the formula used by the U.S. Census Bureau and most of the federal government's statistical gathering apparatus. This is designed to streamline comparisons between the CMI diffusion index and comparable indices.
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Business indices]]

revision.text:
{{For|the baseball player|Dorice Reid (baseball)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=November 2016}}
'''Dorice Reid''' (June 1943 – 16 June 2011), also known by the chiefly title '''Te Tika Mataiapo Dorice Reid''', was a [[Cook Islands|Cook Islander]] [[tourism]] official, [[businesswoman]] and judge.<ref name=cin>{{cite news |first=|last=|title=Te Tika dies suddenly, Influential woman leaders death shocks Polynesia |url=http://www3.cookislandsnews.com/2011/June/Wed15/te-tika.php |work=[[Cook Islands News]] |publisher= |date=2011-06-17 |accessdate=2011-07-01|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110831065341/http://www3.cookislandsnews.com/2011/June/Wed15/te-tika.php |archivedate=2011-08-31|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name=stuff>{{cite news |first=Michael|last=Field|title=Star Cook Islander dies |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/auckland/local-news/5159318/Star-Cook-Islander-dies |work=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |publisher= |date=2011-06-17 |accessdate=2011-07-01}}</ref> Reid enjoyed a long career in Cook Island [[business]], politics and [[tourism]] from the 1970s until her death in 2011.<ref name=stuff/>
==Biography== Dorice Reid was born to parents Leo Morrel and Ruby Peyroux (''[[née]]'' Matamua), on [[Rarotonga]], [[Cook Islands]].<ref name=cin/> She moved from Rarotonga to [[New Zealand]] when she was eight years old.<ref name=cin/>
Reid became very influential among Cook Islanders living in [[Auckland]], New Zealand.<ref name=cin/> She initially worked as a sales representative for [[Air New Zealand]], a [[Radio Pacific]] [[talk show host]] and a journalist and reporter for [[South Pacific Television]].<ref name=cin/> Reid later became the first woman of [[Pacific Island]] descent to be nominated for a seat in the [[Parliament of New Zealand]] by a national political party.<ref name=cin/>
Reid moved back from New Zealand to her birthplace of Rarotonga in 1983.<ref name=cin/> She took a position with the [[Cook Islands Tourist Authority]] as a [[sales manager]] and [[marketer]].<ref name=cin/> In 1985 she and her sister, Jeannine Peyroux, acquired the Little Polynesian Resort in Rarotonga. They renovated the small resort and it won two [[World Travel Awards]].<ref name=cin/>
The members of the Takitumu council, one of the three Vaka councils on Rarotonga, bestowed the chiefly title ''Te Tika Mataiapo'' on Reid during the late 1980s.<ref name=cin/> The title, which is named for the Cook Islands warrior Te Tika, was granted to Reid at a ceremony in [[Marae Te Pou Toru]].<ref name=cin/> Reid declined multiple requests to run for the Cook Islands Parliament, citing incongruity of engaging in politics while bearing a traditional title.<ref name=cin/>
Reid became an advocate for tourism and the preservation of Cook Islands culture. Reid made several pilgrimages to [[Taputapuatea marae]], a traditional religious center of eastern [[Polynesia]] located in the [[commune]] of [[Taputapuatea]], [[Raiatea]], with other Polynesian [[tribal chief|chiefs]].<ref name=cin/> She was also an active member of the [[Cook Islands Voyaging Society]]. In 1995, Reid served as the only female crew member on board the [[Te Au O Tonga]], which sailed to [[Raiatea]], [[Tahiti]], [[Nuku Hiva]] and [[Hawaii]] during a three and a half month voyage.<ref name=cin/> In 2002, she completed a second sailing voyage aboard the ''Te Moana Nui O Kiva'' from her home in Rarotonga to [[Tahiti]], [[Huahine]], [[Raiatea]], [[Tahaa]], [[Bora Bora]] and [[Mitiaro]].<ref name=cin/>
Additionally, Reid was a member five separate Cook Islands environmental agencies and served as a judge for the country.<ref name=cin/> She is credited with the reintroduction of the [[raui system]] to the Cook Islands,<ref name=cin/> a traditional system forbidding access to or use of a resource, such as to a fishing lagoon or shellfish, for a certain period of time.<ref name=nes>{{cite news |first=|last=|title=National Parks and Conservation Areas |url=http://www.environment.gov.ck/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=72&Itemid=95 |work=Cook Islands National Environment Service |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2011-07-01|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707010447/http://www.environment.gov.ck/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=72&Itemid=95 |archivedate=2011-07-07|deadurl=yes}}</ref> The system is traditionally used to preserve scarce food resources and also encourages the protection of the environment.<ref name=nes/>
In April 2011, [[Deputy Prime Minister of the Cook Islands|Deputy Prime Minister]] and [[Foreign Minister]] [[Tom Marsters]] announced Reid's appointment as [[High Commissioner]] of the Cook Islands to New Zealand, based in [[Wellington]].<ref name=rnzi>{{cite news |first=|last=|title=Cook Islands appoints new High Commissioner to New Zealand |url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=60299 |work=[[Radio New Zealand International]] |publisher= |date=2011-04-29 |accessdate=2011-07-01}}</ref> She was to take office in July 2011, succeeding [[Mike Mitchell (Ambassador)|Mike Mitchell]].<ref name=cin/><ref name=rnzi/>
Dorice Reid collapsed while attending a tourism conference in Auckland,<ref name=stuff/> and died at Auckland Hospital at 1 AM on 16 June 2011, aged 67.<ref name=cin/> A resident of [[Kauare]], Rarotonga, she was survived by two nieces and a nephew.<ref name=cin/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110831065341/http://www3.cookislandsnews.com/2011/June/Wed15/te-tika.php Cook Islands News: Te Tika memorial]
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Reid, Dorice}} [[Category:Date of birth missing]] [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:Cook Island businesspeople]] [[Category:Cook Island judges]] [[Category:Cook Island women in politics]] [[Category:People from Rarotonga]] [[Category:People from Auckland]] [[Category:20th-century women politicians]] [[Category:21st-century women politicians]] [[Category:Women judges]] [[Category:20th-century judges]] [[Category:21st-century judges]]

{{coord|39.74587|-104.992819|type:adm3rd_region:US-CO|format=dms|display=title}} [[Image:2006-03-26 Denver Skyline I-25 Speer.jpg|thumb|right|320px|Downtown Denver]]
'''Downtown Denver''' is the main financial, commercial, and entertainment district in [[Denver, Colorado]]. There is over {{convert|23000000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of office space in downtown Denver, with 130,000 workers. The downtown area can be divided into six or seven main districts: [[Union Station, Denver (neighborhood)|Union Station]], [[LoDo]] (however, Union Station is often considered to be part of LoDo), [[Ball Park, Denver (neighborhood)|Ball Park]], [[Central Downtown]], [[Civic Center, Denver|Civic Center]], [[Upper Downtown]], and [[Arapahoe Square]].<ref name="DenverInfill.com">{{cite web| url=http://denverinfill.com/main_map.htm |title=Downtown Denver Districts |publisher=DenverInfill.com |accessdate=2008-12-06}}</ref> Within those districts are many smaller features, districts and squares. Some of the more popular features include the [[16th Street Mall|16th Street]] pedestrian mall, built in 1982, Larimer Square, the re-emerging Theatre District near Curtis and 14th, and [[Civic Center, Denver|Civic Center Park]]. Surrounding neighborhoods include [[Capitol Hill, Denver, Colorado|Capitol Hill]] and [[North Capitol Hill, Denver, Colorado|Uptown]] to the east, [[Highland (Denver)|Highland]] to the west, [[Five Points (Denver)|Five Points]] to the north, and the [[Golden Triangle, Denver, Colorado|Golden Triangle]] to the south.
== Overview == [[File:Denver Colorado from space.jpg|thumb|Astronaut's photograph of Denver, Colorado, taken from the [[International Space Station]]. North is to the upper right of the image.]]
As of 2008, there are 34 buildings in the downtown area reaching over 300 ft.<ref name="Emporis.com">{{cite web| url=http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/ci/bu/sk/li/?id=101307&bt=9&ht=2&sro=0 |title=Denver High Rise Buildings |publisher=Emporis.com |accessdate=2008-12-06}}</ref> This count does not include the recently completed [[One Lincoln Park, Denver|One Lincoln Park]] (380 ft) or the Spire (478 ft) and the [[Four Seasons Hotel Denver|Four Seasons]] (565 ft) both under construction.<ref name="Denver-CityScape.com">{{cite web| url=http://www.denver-cityscape.com/downtownprojects.html |title=New Downtown Denver Projects |publisher=Denver-CityScape.com |accessdate=2008-12-06}}</ref> See the [[List of tallest buildings in Denver]].
== Entertainment == [[Image:Wynkoop&17th.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Looking down 17th Street]] Denver has made a strong effort to centralize its commercial and entertainment interests in the Downtown area. Currently, it is home to both [[Coors Field]] and [[Pepsi Center]], and roughly a mile from nearby [[Sports Authority Field at Mile High]]. LoDo and the 16th Street mall are home to hundreds of bars, restaurants, and cafes, attracting many residents from the metro area and supporting the 10,000 plus residents living in the [[central business district]].<ref name="Downtown Denver Partnership">{{cite web| url=http://www.downtowndenver.com |title=Downtown Denver Partnership |publisher=Downtown Denver Partnership |accessdate=2008-12-06}}</ref> Additionally, Downtown Denver is home to the second largest [[Denver Performing Arts Complex|Performing Arts Center]] in the United States.
== Federal District == Downtown Denver also houses a smaller Federal District consisting of four blocks around Champa, Stout, 19th and 20th streets. This district contains a federal courthouse, the [[Byron G. Rogers Federal Building]], a [[U.S. Court of Appeals]], and a [[US Customs House]]. Not a part of this district is the [[Denver Mint]], which actually lies behind the City and County Building at Civic Park.
==Economy== The [[Anadarko Petroleum Corporation]] operates its Denver office in the Granite Tower in Downtown Denver.<ref>"[http://www.anadarko.com/About/Pages/OfficeLocations.aspx Office locations]." [[Anadarko Petroleum Corporation]]. Retrieved on August 14, 2009.</ref>
=="Urban camping" ban== The Downtown Denver Partnership helped lead the lobbying effort to pass an ordinance that provided the police with a law enforcement tool to move the homeless out of sight of tourists and residents of downtown Denver.<ref name="Downtown Denver Partnership Annual Report 2011-2012">{{cite web| url=http://www.downtowndenver.com/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=N%2fG%2fPqfWvM4%3d&tabid=120 |title=Downtown Denver Partnership Annual Report 2011-2012 |publisher=Downtown Denver Partnership |accessdate=2013-05-28}}</ref> Support for the "Urban Camping" Ban included hotelier [[Walter Isenberg]], Vice Chair of a Downtown Denver Partnership board and major donor to Denver's Road Home, the city agency on homelessness.<ref name="Guest Commentary: Denver's camping ordinance reasonable">{{cite web| url=http://www.denverpost.com/opinion/ci_20427292/denvers-camping-ordinance-reasonable |title=Guest Commentary: Denver's camping ordinance reasonable |publisher=Denver Post |accessdate=2013-06-01}}</ref> The ban, now Sec. 38-86.2. of the Denver Municipal Code, passed on May 14, 2012 and supersedes Sec. 38-86.1. which provided the homeless a safe sanctuary in downtown Denver between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m.<ref name="Sec. 38-86.2. - Unauthorized camping on public or private property prohibited">{{cite web| url=http://library.municode.com/HTML/10257/level4/TITIIREMUCO_CH38OFMIPR_ARTIVOFAGPUORSA_DIV1GE.html#TITIIREMUCO_CH38OFMIPR_ARTIVOFAGPUORSA_DIV1GE_S38-86.2UNCAPUPRPRPR |title=Sec. 38-86.2. - Unauthorized camping on public or private property prohibited |publisher=City of Denver |accessdate=2013-06-01}}</ref> Sponsored by Mayor Michael Hancock and Councilman Albus Brooks, the ban was approved by a vote of 9 to 4 by the Denver City Council.<ref name="Why Our Work Is Important">{{cite web| url=http://denverhomelessoutloud.org/why-is-our-work-important/ |title=Why Our Work Is Important |publisher=Denver Homeless Out Loud |accessdate=2013-05-28}}</ref><ref name="Services to offset Denver camping ban yet to be delivered">{{cite web| url=http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_21884660/services-offset-denver-camping-ban-yet-be-delivered |title=Services to offset Denver camping ban yet to be delivered |publisher=Denver Post |accessdate=2013-06-01}}</ref> A number of organizations are opposing the ban criminalizing homelessness<ref name="Alternatives to Criminalization">{{cite web |url=http://www.usich.gov/issue/alternatives_to_criminalization |title=Alternatives to Criminalization |publisher=United States Interagency on Homelessness |accessdate=2013-05-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130525090841/http://www.usich.gov/issue/alternatives_to_criminalization/ |archivedate=2013-05-25 |df= }}</ref> including Colorado Coalition for the Homeless,<ref name="Homes Not Handcuffs">{{cite web| url=http://www.coloradocoalition.org/advocate/homesnothandcuffs.aspx |title=Homes Not Handcuffs |publisher=Colorado Coalition for the Homeless |accessdate=2013-05-28}}</ref> Denver Catholic Worker, Denver Homeless Out Loud,<ref name="Denver Homeless Out Loud">{{cite web| url=http://denverhomelessoutloud.org/ |title=Denver Homeless Out Loud |publisher=Denver Homeless Out Loud |accessdate=2013-05-28}}</ref> Downtown Denver <ref name="Downtown Denver">{{cite web| url=http://www.downtowndenver.org/ |title=Downtown Denver |publisher=Downtown Denver |accessdate=2013-05-28}}</ref> and Occupy Denver.<ref name="Boycott The Palm">{{cite web| url=http://occupydenver.org/boycott-palm/ |title=Boycott The Palm |publisher=Occupy Denver |accessdate=2013-05-28}}</ref> Denver Homeless Out Loud compiled a report on the impact of the "Urban Camping" Ban after surveying 512 homeless people.<ref name="The Denver Camping Ban: A Report from the Streets">{{cite web| url=http://issuu.com/denverhomelessoutloud/docs/surveyreport |title=The Denver Camping Ban: A Report from the Streets |publisher=Denver Homeless Out Loud |accessdate=2013-06-01}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Neighborhoods of Denver}}

revision.text:
The '''Export Promotion Council of Kenya''' ('''EPC''') is [[Kenya]]’s premier institution in the development and promotion of export trade in the country. Established in 1992, EPC’s primary objective was to address bottlenecks that were facing exporters and producers of export goods and services with a view to increasing the performance of the export sector. The Council was therefore established for the purpose of giving an outward orientation to an economy that was hitherto inward looking. Over time, the EPC has embraced the mandate of co-ordinating and harmonising export development and promotion activities in the country, providing leadership to all national export programmes. Today, EPC is the focal point for export development and promotion activities in the country.
The EPC was established on August 19, 1992 through Legal Notice No. 4342, with the mandate of developing and promoting Kenya’s exports. In pursuit of its mandate, the EPC primary objective is to address bottlenecks facing exporters and producers of export goods and services in order to increase the performance level of the export sector. It also provides a forum for dialogue between the exporting fraternity and relevant public and private sector institutions and organizations through Sectoral Panels..
==Sectors==
The EPC is organized by industrial sector: *[[Horticulture]] and [[agriculture|other Agriculturals]] *[[textile industry|Textiles and Clothing]] *[[Small and medium enterprise|Commercial Crafts and SMEs (Small and Medium Size Enterprises)]] *[[fishery|Fish]] and [[Livestock]] products *[[manufacturing|Other manufactures]] *[[service sector|Services other than tourism]]
==Associated organizations== *[[Center for Business Information in Kenya]] (CBIK) *[[Fresh Produce Export Association of Kenya]] (FPEAK) *[[Kenya Flower Council]]
==Official Site== *[http://www.epckenya.org/ Export Promotion Council official site]
==Associated directory site== *[http://www.buyfromkenya.com/ Exporter's exhibition portal]

{{refimprove|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox fashion designer |name=Francesca Miranda |birth_name = Francesca Miranda |birth_place=[[San Salvador]], [[El Salvador]] |nationality=Salvadoran/American |death_place= |label_name=Francesca Miranda
|significant_design= |awards= |}} '''Francesca Miranda''' is a [[El Salvador|Salvadoran]] [[fashion designer]]. She sells her designs in all over the world.{{cn|date=November 2018}} She has dressed several celebrities such as [[Rebecca Mader]], [[Sofia Milos]], [[Andrea Minski]], [[Elisabeth Röhm]], [[Perrey Reeves]], [[Shenae Grimes]], [[Ashlan Gorse]], [[Nadia Dawn]], [[Shaun Toub|Shaun Toub's]] wife Lorena Toub, [[Teyonah Parris]] and [[Broderick Johnson|Broderick Johnson's]] wife Jennifer.[http://www.francescamiranda.com/2010/10/celebrities/ 'Francesca Miranda-Celebrities']. Retrieved 1 June 2011. {{dead link|date=November 2018}} In 2015, [[Adele]] chose to feature one of her wedding dress designs in an article in ''[[Glamour (magazine)|Glamour]]'' magazine.Kim Fusaro, [http://www.glamour.com/story/adele-wedding-dresses "8 One-of-a-Kind Wedding Dresses for Adele, in Case Her Love Story Includes a Wedding"], ''Glamour'', December 2015. Retrieved 18 November 2018. ==Early life and education== Miranda is one of five children of Gloria Gonzales de Miranda, an Ohioan entrepreneur of Spanish parents, and the Spanish-Italian lawyer and politician [[Ruy Cesar Miranda Lupone]] of an affluent family in the Central American country.[http://www.elsalvador.com/mujeres/2005/11/entrevista/index.asp Karen Funes, 'Francesca Miranda vino para quedarse', ''Mujeres'' (2004)]. Retrieved 4 September 2006. {{dead link|date=November 2018}} Miranda studied [[fashion merchandising]] at [[University of South Florida]] and Lake Land College, both in [[Florida]]. ==Brand and career== Miranda began to design under the Xango brand in 1995. Three years later she put her own name to her leading edge menswear designs. Having established herself as a menswear designer, in 2000 Miranda created City People, a range of clothes for women. City People has embroidery, fitted trousers and transparent blouses.[http://www.terra.com/especiales/lamoda/moda_en_miami/francesca_miranda/francesca_miranda.html Luciano Lamberto, 'Francesca Miranda', ''El Mundo de la Moda'' (2001)]. Retrieved 4 September 2006. {{dead link|date=November 2018}} Her 2001 collection was inspired by the works of the Colombian novelist [[Gabriel García Márquez]].[http://www.elheraldo.com.co/revistas/gente/01-08-25/noti7.htm Loor Naissir, 'Francesca Miranda: Crónica de una moda anunciada', ''Gente'' (25 August 2001)]. Retrieved 4 September 2006. {{dead link|date=November 2018}} In 1994, Miranda launched a menswear casual line for department stores in Colombia. She has been invited to participate in Colombiamoda, Colombia’s fashion industry trade show. In 1997 she inaugurated her first boutique with her label, "Francesca Miranda" with a menswear line. In 2000 she expanded to women's wear when opening her flagship store in Barranquilla, Colombia where she sells both men and women’s Pret A Porter, and Evening wear lines. In 2001, she received from Fashion TV Paris, an award for best runway during Miami Fashion Week, and opened her second store in Colombia’s capital, Bogota. Four years later, she opened her first Central American store, in her native San Salvador. Her collections are represented in the United States and Canada by Group 868 Inc showroom in New York. In 2010, alongside Group 868 Inc showroom, she launched her first bridal collection. Miranda had done bridal before, but only custom made gowns. In November 2010, Miranda opened her third store in Colombia in the city of [[Cartagena, Colombia|Cartagena]]. Her stores carry men's and women's collections, leather handbags for women, decorative pieces for the home and Colombian art pieces. ==Personal life== After her marriage to Francisco Jassir in 1983 she moved to her husband's hometown of [[Barranquilla]], Colombia, where she opened her first boutique. Its success led to the opening of a new one in Cartagena. Her first boutique outside Colombia was opened in [[El Salvador]]. The couple have three children: Daniella Jassir Miranda, Francisco Jassir Miranda and Andrea Sofía Jassir Miranda. Daniella is a singer and fashion marketer , working as a marketing director of her mother's brand and her own. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.francescamiranda.com/}} *{{Commonscat-inline|Francesca Miranda}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Miranda, Francesco}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Businesspeople in fashion]] [[Category:Salvadoran fashion designers]] [[Category:Salvadoran businesspeople]] [[Category:University of Tampa alumni]] [[Category:Salvadoran women in business]]
