{{Infobox Officeholder |name = Kosit Panpiemras |native_name = โฆสิต ปั้นเปี่ยมรัษฎ์ |image = |honorific-suffix = |office1 = [[Prime Minister of Thailand|Deputy Prime Minister of Thailand]] |primeminister1 = [[Surayud Chulanont]] |term_start1 = 9 October 2006 |term_end1 = 6 February 2008 |predecessor1 = |successor1 = |office2 = [[Ministry of Industry (Thailand)|Minister of Industry]] |primeminister2 = [[Surayud Chulanont]] |term_start2 = 9 October 2006 |term_end2 = 6 February 2008 |predecessor2 = [[Suriya Juangroongruangkit]] |successor2 = [[Suwit Khunkitti]] |primeminister3 = [[Banharn Silpa-archa]] |term_start3 = 27 September 1996 |term_end3 = 24 November 1996 |predecessor3 = [[Chaiwat Sinsuwong]] |successor3 = [[Korn Dabbaransi]] |office4 = [[Ministry of Finance (Thailand)|Finance Minister of Thailand]] |primeminister4 = [[Chavalit Yongchaiyudh]] |term_start4 = 24 October 1997 |term_end4 = 14 November 1997 |predecessor4 = [[Thanong Bidaya]] |successor4 = [[Tharin Nimmanhaemin]] |office5 = [[Ministry of Agriculture and Cooperatives (Thailand)|Minister of Agriculture and Cooperatives]] |primeminister5 = [[Anand Panyarachun]] |term_start5 = 10 June 1992 |term_end5 = 22 September 1992 |predecessor5 = [[Pinit Juntarasurin]] |successor5 = [[Nipon Prompan]] |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date|1943|05|28|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Bangkok]], [[Siam]] |death_date = {{death date and age|2016|06|01|1943|05|28|df=y}} |death_place = [[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]] |party = |spouse = Yubhana Panpiemras |children = |alma_mater = [[Saint Gabriel's College]]
[[Chulalongkorn University]]
[[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]] |profession = |religion = [[Theravada]] [[Buddhism]] |signature = |height={{height|m=1.67|precision=0}}}} '''Kosit Panpiemras''' (28 May 1943 – 1 June 2016) was a Thai businessman and politician. He was chairman of [[Bangkok Bank]], a leading [[Thailand|Thai]] [[commercial bank]], between 1999 and 2016. Following the [[2006 Thailand coup]], he was appointed advisor to the military junta.[http://www.bangkokpost.com/News/27Sep2006_news15.php CDR advisers not told of appointments]. ''[[Bangkok Post]]''. 27 September 2006 He previously held a number of cabinet posts under different government administrations. He died of cancer on 1 June 2016.{{cite news|title=BBL chairman Kosit dies at 73|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/general/997813/bbl-chairman-kosit-dies-at-73|date=1 June 2016|work=[[Bangkok Post]]}} ==References== {{DEFAULTSORT:Kosit Panpiemras}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:2016 deaths]] [[Category:Thai businesspeople]] [[Category:Chulalongkorn University alumni]] [[Category:Deputy Prime Ministers of Thailand]] [[Category:Members of the Senate of Thailand]] [[Category:Ministers of Finance of Thailand]] {{Thailand-politician-stub}}

{{Infobox video game |title = Leading Company |image = [[Image:Leading Company SFC.jpg|frameless|Leading Company]] |caption = Super Famicom cover art |developer = |publisher = [[Koei]] |composer = Yoshihisa Tomabechi
[[Mark Soskin]]
Kazumasa Mitsui |series = ''[[Koei#Executive Series|Koei Executive Series]]'' |released = '''Super Famicom:''' {{vgrelease|JP|February 26, 1993{{cite web| url = http://www.gamefaqs.com/console/snes/data/570914.html| title = Release date (Super NES) | publisher = [[GameFAQs]] | date = | accessdate = 2008-05-23}}}} '''Sharp X68000:''' {{vgrelease|JP|July 30, 1992{{cite web| url = http://www.gamefaqs.com/x68000/656976-leading-company/data| title = Release date (Sharp X68000) | publisher = GameFAQs | date = | accessdate = 2012-01-14}}}} |genre = [[Strategy video game|Strategy game involving construction]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]]
[[multiplayer video game|Multiplayer]] (up to 4 players) |platforms = [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|Super Famicom]]
[[NEC PC-9801]]
[[Sharp X68000]]
[[FM Towns]] }} {{nihongo|'''''Leading Company'''''|リーディングカンパニー}}{{cite web | url = http://superfamicom.org/info/leading-company/| title = Japanese title/additional media information | publisher = superfamicom.org | date = | accessdate = 2010-10-01}} is a [[strategy video game|construction-oriented strategy]] video game that was released for both the [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|Super Famicom]], [[NEC PC-9801]], [[Sharp X68000]] and [[FM Towns]]. ==Summary== [[File:LeadingCompanyJVDCorporateHQScreenshot.jpg|left|thumb|This player is focusing on adjusting the levels of production at his JVD (JVC) corporate headquarters.]] The traditional definition of a '''leading company''' is a corporation that currently dominates the "corporate wars" against their competitors. Its [[employee]]s are considered by most people to be winning the "[[rat race]]." Both versions of this game were released to an exclusively [[Japan]]ese market. However, the NEC PC-9801 version has sharper [[Computer graphics|graphics]] and the ability to use a [[mouse (computing)|mouse]]. Instead of abstract colors (to depict control of each square of the board), buildings are used to depict a typical Japanese residential neighborhood. A [[Amusement park|theme park]] is visibily shown on an island in the PC-9801 version to depict recreational opportunities while the interior of the corporate headquarters is seen in the Sharp X68000 version. The game challenges young people to create their own business empire by researching and marketing better [[VHS]] machines for the [[Demographics of Japan|Japanese consumers]]. In both version of the game, the player is introduced to jazzy instrumental song being played in the background while [[neon]] pictures of various people fly across the screen. As of 2011, there has been no attempt to produce an [[English language]] version for this game either through official channels or through unofficial emulator translator groups. This game is considered to be in Japanese for the full duration of the game, making literacy skills in Japanese mandatory. Only the brand names themselves use [[ASCII]] letters; all other words use the [[Japanese alphabet]]. There are only two time periods in the game and [[jazz music]] plays throughout the entire game. The player can either start in the 1970s when [[Videocassette recorder|VCRs]] were beginning to be researched in Japan or in the [[1980s in Japan|1980s]] when VHS (and video cassette recorders) were beginning to come of age. Up to eight buildings can be constructed on the corporation's property to build and research new technology. However, three buildings are already established at the start of the game. Each product that he or she manufactures has a separate [[profit chart]]. When an older model goes down in profits, research and manufacture a newer one (don't forget to discontinue the older one first) and make more money from willing Japanese customers.{{cite web | url =https://archive.is/03jpd| title = Basic game overview | publisher = AXL | date = | accessdate = 2010-09-29}} It is considered to be the job of the player to try to keep his chosen corporation profitable by creating new VHS machines while making sure that people still spend money on the ones being made. If they go down to zero or less, then his or her company goes [[bankruptcy|bankrupt]]. At this point, he or she loses the game. When a company goes bankrupt, a television news screen appears with the English word "[[Dissolution (law)|DISSOLVED]]" right on the picture caption. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://fullmotionvideo.free.fr/screen/a.html NEC PC9801 images] {{DEFAULTSORT:Leading Company}} [[Category:1993 video games]] [[Category:Business simulation games]] [[Category:Japan-exclusive video games]] [[Category:Koei games]] [[Category:NEC PC-9801 games]] [[Category:Sharp X68000 games]] [[Category:Super Nintendo Entertainment System games]] [[Category:FM Towns games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Video games set in the 1970s]] [[Category:Video games set in the 1980s]] [[Category:Video games set in the 1990s]] [[Category:Video games set in Japan]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]]

{{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Chinese name|[[Li (surname 李)|Li (李)]]}} {{Infobox person | name = Li Yonghong | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1969|9|16|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Huazhou, Guangdong|Huazhou]], [[Guangdong]], China<ref name="Nanfang Weekend">{{cite news|url=http://www.infzm.com/content/131309|script-title=zh:收了AC米兰，谁是李勇鸿？|trans-title=acquires AC Milan, who is Li Yonghong?|date=6 December 2017|access-date=22 May 2018|work=Nanfang Weekend|publisher=Nanfang Media Group|language=zh-cn|author=施南}}</ref> | nationality = China | citizenship = {{aligned table|fullwidth=y|style=text-align: left; font-size: 100%;|mainland China|(1969–1994)|Hong Kong|(1994–present)}} | other_names = | father = Li Naizhi | family = {{aligned table|fullwidth=y|style=text-align: left; font-size: 100%;|Li Hongqiang|(brother)|Li Yongfei|(brother)}} | occupation = businessman<ref name=cnstock/> | years_active = | known_for = {{ubl|{{nowrap|Former owner of Duolun Investment (HK)}}|Former [[general manager|GM]] of Chief Power Real Estate| Former owner of [[A.C. Milan]]}} | net_worth = }} {{Chinese|title=Li Yong Hong|s=李勇鸿|t=李勇鴻|p=Li Yǒnghóng|order=st}} '''Li Yonghong''' (born 16 September 1969)<ref name=court/><ref name=csrc/> is a Chinese businessman. He was known for his short lived ownership on [[A.C. Milan|Milan]], as well as his stock market transactions in the mainland China.
Li Yonghong was born in Guantang Village, Daqiao Town, [[Huazhou, Guangdong|Huazhou]], [[Maoming]], Guangdong Province.<ref name="Nanfang Weekend"/> He also had a citizenship in Hong Kong S.A.R. of China by migrating there in 1994 (claimed by himself),<ref name=csrc>{{cite web|url=http://www.csrc.gov.cn/pub/shanghai/xzcf/201401/t20140116_242648.htm|title=行政处罚决定书：沪［2013］1号|date=29 November 2013|access-date=13 April 2017|publisher=China Securities Regulatory Commission (Shanghai Bureau)|language=Chinese}}</ref><ref name=Duolun2011>{{cite web|url=http://www.cninfo.com.cn/finalpage/2011-12-06/60287610.PDF|title=详式权益变动报告书|date=6 December 2011|access-date=13 April 2017|work=Duolun|publisher=hosted by cninfo.com.cn|language=Chinese}}</ref> which was considered as a "foreign" investor in mainland China due to separate legal jurisdiction of Hong Kong from the rest of China.
==Career== According to a C.V. provided by Li Yonghong to Duolun Industry, Li Yonghong was the director and general manager of a Hong Kong incorporated company Enson Enterprises Limited ({{zh|t=安順企業有限公司}}) from 1994 to 1997 (a company dissolved by striking-off in 2000); the director and general manager of a [[Chongqing]]-based company ({{zh|s=爱普科技|l=Aipu Technology}}) from 1997 to 2005, as well as chairman and CEO of Hong Kong-incorporated "Grand Dragon International Holdings Co., Ltd." from 2005.<ref name=Duolun2011/>
However, according to the filings in Hong Kong Companies Registry, there was no such Li Yonghong in the board of directors of Enson Enterprises,<ref>Annual Return in 1995, 1996, 1997 of Enson Enterprises to Hong Kong Companies Registry</ref> nor in Grand Dragon.<ref>Annual Return in 2006, 2007, 2016, 2017 of Grand Dragon to Hong Kong Companies Registry</ref>
Instead, Li Yonghong was the director of China Power Group (HK) Limited ({{zh|t=華力寶集團(香港)有限公司}}), Hong Kong China Power Books Publication Co., Ltd. ({{zh|t=香港華力寶圖書出版有限公司}}), Noble Wisdom Development Limited ({{zh|t=卓彥發展有限公司}}) and LYH Investment Limited, according to the database of Hong Kong Companies Registry.
==A.C. Milan== In August 2016, [[Fininvest]], the parent company of Italian football club [[A.C. Milan]], signed a preliminary agreement with a Chinese investment management company '''Sino-Europe Sports Investment Management Changxing Co., Ltd.''' ({{zh|s=中欧体育投资管理长兴有限公司}}) to sell the club for €740 million (including €220 million indebtedness of the company), valued on 30 June 2016 (A further €90 million cost of the club from 1 July to the closing date<ref name=pressreleaseApril2017/> was added to the valuation). Sino-Europe Sports paid Fininvest €100 million immediately after the deal as a deposit, and the closing date of the deal was set at December 2016.<ref name="selling">{{cite web |title=Comunicato Stampa – Milan: Fininvest firma preliminare di vendita con cordata cinese |trans-title=Press Release – Milan: Fininvest signs preliminary selling agreement with Chinese group of investors |url=http://www.fininvest.it/assets/press/it/CS_Fininvest-Milan_5.08.16.pdf |work=fininvest.it |publisher=[[Fininvest]] |date=5 August 2016 |accessdate=9 August 2016 |language=Italian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fininvest.it/assets/press/en/CS%20ENG_caparra%20Milan_6.9.16.pdf|title=Fininvest: receipt of 85 million euros, the second installment of the down payment for the purchase of AC Milan|date=6 September 2016|access-date=6 September 2016|publisher=Fininvest}}</ref>
Sino-Europe Sports, registered in [[Changxing County]], according to Chinese Government's National Enterprise Credit Information Publicity System, was solely owned by mainland Chinese citizen Chen Huashan ({{zh|s=陈华山}}) with a [[share capital]] of just {{CNY|100 million}}.<ref name=Chinesedatabase>Filings in National Enterprise Credit Information Publicity System</ref> However, it was reported that Li Yonghong and a private equity fund ({{zh|s=海峡中欧私募投资基金}}) of [[Haixia Capital Management]] were the true owner of Sino-Europe Sports.<ref name="selling"/> Moreover, Sino-Europe Sports was represented by David Han Li in the signing of the contracts with Fininvest.<ref name="selling"/><ref name=pressreleaseApril2017/>
In the same month Sino-Europe Sports found a private equity fund (incorporated as a [[limited partnership]] as {{lang|zh|中欧体育投资长兴合伙企业}}<ref name=Chinesedatabase/>) to raise fund to acquire Milan, which Chinese listed company [[Rongyu Group]] (formerly known as Jilin Yongda Group) signed an agreement to subscribe {{CNY|300 million}} deferred share, which would only paid-in the capital when the fund raise enough capital in ordinary and preference share.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cninfo.com.cn/cninfo-new/disclosure/szse_sme/bulletin_detail/true/1202354621?announceTime=2016-06-03%2011:49|title=关于全资子公司永大创新金融服务(深圳)有限公司拟参与投资产业并购基金的公告|date=2 June 2016|accessdate=16 August 2016|work=Jilin Yongda Group|publisher=Hosted by cninfo.com.cn|language=Chinese}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cninfo.com.cn/cninfo-new/disclosure/szse_sme/bulletin_detail/true/1202562697?announceTime=2016-08-13|title=关于中欧体育投资管理长兴有限公司与Fininvest S.p.A.签署收购A.C.米兰俱乐部99.93%股权协议的公告|date=12 August 2016|accessdate=16 August 2016|work=Jilin Yongda Group|publisher=Hosted by cninfo.com.cn|language=Chinese}}</ref>
However, Sino-Europe Sports failed to pay the residual sum in December, and the deal was delayed to March 2017. Sino-Europe Sports paid a second deposit of €100 million<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fininvest.it/assets/press/en/Joint%20PR%20Fininvest-SES_7.12.16.pdf|title=AC Milan: agreement for the closing by March 3rd 2017. Further EUR100 million deposit from SES|date=7 December 2016|access-date=3 March 2017|publisher=Fininvest}}</ref> (making the total deposit was €200 million) to Fininvest via Hong Kong subsidiaries of Sino-Europe Sports: '''Rossoneri Sport Investment Co., Ltd.''' and Rossoneri Champion Co., Ltd.. However, according to the filing in Hong Kong Companies Registry, Rossoneri Sport Investment borrowed HK$830 million (around €100 million according to exchange rate at that time) from a mystery [[British Virgin Islands|BVI]]-incorporated company Willy Shine International Holdings Limited ({{zh|t=威陽國際控股有限公司}}) on 13 December 2016.<ref name=HKCR/> The loan was refurbished on 23 January 2017.<ref name=HKCR/> In February 2017, Rossoneri Sport Investment (of Hong Kong) was recapitalised by yet another mystery BVI-incorporated company '''Rossoneri Advanced Co., Ltd.''' for HK$864.5 million, making Sino-Europe Sports became a minority shareholder on Rossoneri Sport Investment (of Hong Kong) for HK$100 million share, or 10.37%,<ref name=HKCR/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.calcioefinanza.com/2017/03/24/milan-sino-europe-sports-opens-new-offshore-company-fund-third-e100m-deposit/|title=Milan, Sino Europe Sports opens new offshore company to fund third €100M deposit|date=24 March 2017|access-date=15 April 2017|work=Calcio e Finanza}}</ref> although Chen remained as the sole director of Rossoneri Sport Investment and 100% owner of the entire share capital of Rossoneri Champion.<ref name=HKCR>Filings in Hong Kong Companies Registry (https://www.icris.cr.gov.hk)</ref> The two BVI companies had raised a concern in Italy on who was the actual investors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://carlofesta.blog.ilsole24ore.com/2017/01/05/milan-tra-il-mistero-delle-isole-vergini-e-i-dubbi-di-fassone/|title=Milan, tra il mistero delle Isole Vergini e i dubbi di Fassone|date=5 January 2017|access-date=13 April 2017|work=Il Sole 24|first=Carlo|last=Festa|department ="The Insider" column|language=Italian}}</ref>
It was reported that the private equity fund had received a loan from [[Elliott Management Corporation]] to finalised the closing, after Sino-Europe Sports failed to pay the residual sum again in March 2017.<ref>{{cite news|work=Reuters Editorial |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-acmilan-m-a-elliott-idUSKBN16Y1CC |title=Elliott rescues deal to sell soccer club AC Milan |agency=Reuters |date=27 March 2017 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.corriere.it/sport/calcio/serie-a/2016-2017/notizie/dalla-disperazione-303-milioni-ecco-come-cinese-yonghong-li-ha-trovato-soldi-compra-milan-2c92de08-1264-11e7-a037-a2d5af436a5d.shtml|title=Dalla disperazione ai 303 milioni Ecco come il cinese Yonghong Li ha salvato l'operazione Milan |date=26 March 2017|orig-year=modified on 27 March 2017|access-date=13 April 2017|work=Corriere della Sera|publisher=RCS MediaGroup|language=Italian}}</ref> According to ''Calcio e Finanza'', Elliott used two associate companies King George Investments and Genio Investments to finance the parent company of Milan<ref>http://www.calcioefinanza.it/2017/04/12/milan-project-redblack-holding-blue-skye-yonghong-li/</ref> that was owned by Li indirectly. It was also reported that another private equity fund, Blue Skye, also financed the deal.<ref>http://en.calcioefinanza.com/2017/04/24/milan-chinese-hands-closer-look-acquisition-ac-milan/</ref>
On 13 April 2017, the sale was officially finalised, which '''Rossoneri Sport Investment Luxembourg [[Société à responsabilité limitée|Sàrl]]''' became the new direct parent company of the club.<ref name=sell>{{cite web|url=http://www.football-italia.net/101063/official-berlusconi-sells-milan|title=Official Berlusconi sells Milan|publisher=Football Italia|date=13 April 2017|accessdate=13 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.football-italia.net/101067/li-%E2%80%98well-bring-milan-back%E2%80%99|title=Li: 'We'll bring Milan back'|publisher=Football Italia|date=13 April 2017|accessdate=13 April 2017}}</ref><ref name=pressreleaseApril2017>{{cite web|url=http://www.fininvest.it/assets/press/it/CS%20CONGIUNTO_closing%20Milan_13.4.17.pdf|title=Comunicato congiunto Fininvest-Rossoneri Sport Inv.Lux – CLOSING AC MILAN|date=13 April 2017|access-date=13 April 2017|publisher=Fininvest}}</ref> Rossoneri Luxembourg, as of January 2017 was owned by Hong Kong-company Rossoneri Sport Investment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.calcioefinanza.it/2017/01/06/rossoneri-sport-investment-luxembourg-holding-milan/|title=Rossoneri Sport Investment Luxembourg, ecco la holding in Lussemburgo per il Milan|date=6 January 2017|access-date=15 April 2017|publisher=Calcio e Finanza|language=Italian}}</ref> On 14 April Li Yonghong was confirmed as the new chairman of the club, with [[Marco Fassone]] was confirmed as CEO ({{lang-it|Amministratore Delegato}}).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.football-italia.net/101121/official-yonghong-li-new-milan-president|title=Official: Yonghong Li new Milan president|publisher=Football Italia|date=14 April 2017|accessdate=14 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.acmilan.com/it/news/comunicati-ufficiali/2017-04-14/comunicato-stampa|title=L'Assemblea dei soci nomina il nuovo Consiglio di Amministrazione di AC Milan S.p.A.|date=14 April 2017|access-date=15 April 2017|publisher=A.C. Milan|language=Italian}}</ref> It was reported that the final price of the club was €606 million (the price included a refurbishment of a €90m credit line of Fininvest to Milan), excluding the refurbishment of the club debt.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.milanofinanza.it/news/fininvest-25-milioni-spesi-per-vendere-il-milan-201708171654229403|title= Fininvest, 25 milioni spesi per vendere il Milan |date=17 August 2017|access-date=7 September 2017|work=[[MF Milano Finanza]]|language=Italian}}</ref> The club had planned to issue 2 tranches of [[corporate bond]]s for a total of €128m,<ref name=gazetta201705>{{cite press release|url=http://www.gazzettaufficiale.it/eli/id/2017/05/02/TX17AAA4842/p2|title=Convocazione di assemblea|date=2 May 2017|access-date=7 September 2017|first=Arrigo|last=Roveda|publisher=A.C. Milan|via=''Gazzetta Ufficiale''|language=Italian}}</ref> ({{ISIN|IT0005254435}} and {{ISIN|IT0005254443}}) as well as a recapitalization of a maximum of €60m, in order to funding the club in 2017 after the takeover.<ref name=gazetta201705/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.acmilan.com/it/club/aumento-di-capitale|title=AUMENTO DI CAPITALE 2017|date=2017|orig-year=circa|access-date=7 September 2017|publisher=A.C. Milan}}</ref>
On 22 October 2017, it was revealed by [[David Webb (Hong Kong activist)|David Webb]] that [[Teamway International Group Holdings|Teamway International Group]] (known as Jin Bao Bao at that time), a small-sized Hong Kong-listed company, had lent US$8.3 million (approx. HK$65 million by [[Linked exchange rate system in Hong Kong|the narrow band floating exchange rate]]) to Hong Kong-based Rossoneri Sport Investment.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://webb-site.com//articles/teamway.asp|first=David|last=Webb|author-link=David Webb (Hong Kong activist)|title=Questions on Teamway (1239) and a bit of soccer|date= 22 October 2017|website=webb-site.com|access-date=23 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/financeestate/art/20171023/20191857|title=Zhōng zī mǎi qǐ AC mǐ lán yí tòu guò ké gǔ chóu qián|script-title=zh:中資買起AC米蘭 疑透過殼股籌錢 |date=23 October 2017|access-date=23 October 2017|newspaper=Apple Daily|publication-place=Hong Kong|publisher=Next Digital|language=zh-hk}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://carlofesta.blog.ilsole24ore.com/2017/10/24/milan-lo-scoop-dei-tifosi-i-soldi-dellaumento-prestata-a-li-con-interessi-del-14/|title=Milan, lo scoop dei tifosi: i soldi dell’aumento prestati a Li con interessi del 14%|date=24 October 2017|access-date=25 October 2017|department=Blog|newspaper=Il Sole 24 Ore|first= Carlo|last=Festa|language=Italian||publication-place=Milan}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.pressreader.com/italy/la-gazzetta-dello-sport/20171025/281835758947561|title=Nuovo prestito a Li Yonghong Ad agosto 7 milioni al 14%|date=25 October 2017|access-date=25 October 2017|newspaper=La Gazzetta dello Sport|publisher=RCS MediaGroup|publication-place=Milan|language=Italian|via=pressreader.com}}</ref> According to the press release by Teamway (known as Jin Bao Bao at that time) on 29 August 2017, it was also revealed that Rossoneri Advance[d] was owned by Li Yonghong himself;<ref name=Teamway>{{cite press release|url=http://www.hkexnews.hk/listedco/listconews/SEHK/2017/0829/LTN20170829031.pdf|title=Disclosable transaction: provision of loan facility |date=29 August 2017|orig-year=Written on 28 August 2017|access-date=23 October 2017|publisher=Jin Bao Bao Holdings|via=Hong Kong Exchange and Clearing Limited|quote=The Facility is secured by: (a) a deed of share charge executed by the Chargor in favour of the Lender...}}</ref> Li [[Equitable charge|charged]] the entire issued shares of Rossoneri Advance[d] to Teamway International Group as collateral.<ref name=Teamway/> In September 2017, Rossoneri Sport Investment also filed a revised "Annual Return" to reflect the "correct" condition in June 2017, that Rossoneri Advance owned all the shares of the company.<ref name=HKCR/> On 31 October 2017, Reuters reported that Li only paid-in €27 million out of €60 million capital increase of AC Milan so far,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://it.reuters.com/article/businessNews/idITKBN1D01Q5-OITBS|title=AC Milan, bilancio: da analisi covenant prestiti no criticità, fiducia in rinegoziazione debito|date=31 October 2017|access-date=31 October 2017|agency=Reuters|first=Elvira|last=Pollina|language=Italian}}</ref> matching the concern of his financial condition, willingness and ability to recapitalize Milan with such a high interest rate on a small amount of loan.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.calciomercato.com/en/news/milan-new-evidence-points-to-dire-financial-situation-46777|title=Milan: new evidence points to dire financial situation|date=24 October 2017|access-date=31 October 2017|website=calciomercato.com|publisher=Calcioinfinito|publication-place=Milan}}</ref> Last but not the least, Li failed to refurbished the loan in February 2018, but was allowed to extended for a month, with a interest rate of 24% p.a..<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.hkexnews.hk/listedco/listconews/SEHK/2018/0305/LTN201803051856.pdf|title=DISCLOSEABLE TRANSACTION SUPPLEMENTAL DEED RELATING TO PROVISION OF LOAN FACILITY|date=5 March 2018|access-date=25 March 2018|publisher=Teamway International Group|via=Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing website}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://carlofesta.blog.ilsole24ore.com/2018/03/11/milan-mr-li-proroga-i-debiti-a-hong-hong-a-interessi-del-24-e-si-fa-garantire-dalla-moglie/|title=Milan, Mr Li proroga i debiti a Hong Kong a interessi del 24% e si fa garantire dalla moglie|date=11 March 2018|access-date=25 March 2018|work=Il Sole 24 Ore|department="The Insider" column|first=Carlo|last=Festa|language=Italian}}</ref>
On 16 November 2017, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that Li alleged himself had a mining empire to Italian football officials, which "was hardly known even in mining circles [of China]."<ref name=NYT2017>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/16/business/dealbook/china-soccer-acmilan-ownership.html|title=China's Soccer Push Puts a Storied Team Under Murky Ownership|date=16 November 2017|access-date=21 November 2017|newspaper=The New York Times|first1=Sui-Lee|last1=Wee|first2=Ryan|last2=Mcmorrow|first3=Tariq|last3=Panja|others=Other contributors: Rory Smith, Zhang Tiantian and Zoe Mou|url-access=limited}}</ref> The mining empire, on paper record, was owned by other people.<ref name=NYT2017/> However, the newspaper also stated that "Some wealthy people in China list their holdings under the names of relatives or associates to avoid scrutiny".<ref name=NYT2017/> At the same time, UEFA was not convinced to a proposal from Milan, regarding a voluntary agreement that aiming to delay the deadline of break-even requirement of [[UEFA Financial Fair Play Regulations]], according to the report of ''[[La Gazzetta dello Sport]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/Serie-A/Milan/21-11-2017/marca-il-milan-rischia-esclusione-coppe-europee-club-nessuna-comunicazione-uefa-230782082353.shtml|title= Marca: "Il Milan rischia l'esclusione dalle coppe". Il club si dice sorpreso |date=21 November 2017|access-date=21 November 2017|location=Milan|newspaper=La Gazzetta dello Sport|publisher=RCS MediaGroup|language=Italian}}</ref> It was formally rejected in December by the UEFA, citing " there are still uncertainties in relation to the refinancing of the loans to be paid back in October 2018 and the financial guarantees provided by the main shareholder.";<ref>{{cite press release|url=https://www.uefa.com/insideuefa/protecting-the-game/club-licensing-and-financial-fair-play/news/newsid=2526997.html|title=AC Milan request for voluntary agreement rejected|date=15 December 2017|access-date=25 March 2018|department=The Investigatory Chamber of Club Financial Control Body|publisher=UEFA}}</ref> ''[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]'' speculated that the club may face discipline action regarding the club's summer spending.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/en/football/international-football/2017/11/21/5a140194268e3e74058b4647.html|title=AC Milan face exclusion from European football|date=21 November 2017|access-date=21 November 2017|newspaper=Marca|first=José Félix|last=Díaz|translator-first=Marc|translator-last=Mayo|publisher=RCS MediaGroup}}</ref> Eventually Milan was banned by UEFA from European competition for 2018–19 season, citing "the break-even requirement".<ref>{{cite press release|url=https://www.uefa.com/insideuefa/about-uefa/news/newsid=2563654.html|title=CFCB Adjudicatory Chamber renders AC Milan decision|date=27 June 2018|accessdate=8 July 2018|department=The Adjudicatory Chamber of the Club Financial Control Body|publisher=UEFA}}</ref> It was reported that Milan failed to meet the aggregate break-even requirement for the period from 2014 to 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/Serie-A/Milan/25-06-2018/milan-fuori-coppe-un-anno-sentenza-uefa-28085562344.shtml?refresh_ce-cp|title=Milan fuori dalle coppe per un anno: la sentenza Uefa|date=27 June 2018|accessdate=8 July 2018|newspaper=La Gazzetta dello Sport|publisher=RCS MediaGroup|publication-place=Milan|language=Italian}}</ref>
In July 2018, Li defaulted on his debt to [[Elliott Management]], in the process losing the club to the vulture fund.{{cn|date=July 2018}} On 12 July 2018, Elliott officially strike-off Li's holding company Rossoneri Champion Inv. Lux. as a shareholder of Milan's direct parent company Rossoneri Sport Inv. Lux..<ref>https://gd.lu/rcsl/4j3ZH8</ref> According to the press release of [[Teamway International Group]], Li also defaulted the loan from Teamway International Group.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.hkexnews.hk/listedco/listconews/SEHK/2018/0830/LTN201808301185.pdf|title=ANNOUNCEMENT OF INTERIM RESULTS FOR THE SIX MONTHS ENDED 30 JUNE 2018|date=30 August 2018|accessdate=3 September 2018|publisher=Teamway International Group|via=Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing website}}</ref> {{chart top|structure of Sino-Europe Sports (as of January 2017)}} {{chart/start}} {{chart|Chen|-|.|unknown|Chen=Chen Huashan|unknown=?}} {{chart| |!| | |!| |!}} {{chart|SES|~|fund|fund=2 private equity funds|SES=Sino-Europe Sports Investment Management Changxing}} {{chart| |:| | | |!}} {{chart|SESLP|-|-|'|fund=2 private equity funds|SESLP=Sino-Europe Sports Investment Changxing [[Limited Partnership|LP]]}} {{chart| |!}} {{chart|RSIChangxing|RSIChangxing=Rossoneri Sport Investment Management Changxing }} {{chart| |!}} {{chart|RSI|RSI=Rossoneri Sport Investment}} {{chart| |)|-|-|-|.| }} {{chart|lux||champion|lux=Rossoneri Sport Investment Luxembourg|champion=Rossoneri Champion}} {{chart/end}} {{chart bottom}} {{chart top|structure of AC Milan Group (as of June 2017)<ref>https://www.lbr.lu</ref>}} {{chart/start}} {{chart|Li|Li=Li Yonghong}} {{chart| |!|}} {{chart|Advanced|Advanced=Rossoneri Advance[d] }} {{chart| |!|}} {{chart|RSI| | | | | |Elliott|RSI=Rossoneri Sport Investment|Elliott={{ubl|Blue Skye Financial Partners|King George Investments|Genio Investments}} }} {{chart| |)|-|-|-|.| | | |!| }} {{chart|championlux||champion||redblack|champion=Rossoneri Champion|championlux=Rossoneri Champion Investment Luxembourg |redblack=Project Redblack }} {{chart| |)|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|'| }} {{chart|lux||lux=Rossoneri Sport Investment Luxembourg}} {{chart| |!|}} {{chart|SpA|SpA=[[A.C. Milan]]}} {{chart/end}} {{chart bottom}}
==Controversies== ===Jade Valley Group=== It was reported that Li Yonghong is the son of Li Naizhi ({{zh|s=李乃志}}) and younger brother of Li Yongfei ({{zh|s=李勇飞}}), which were arrested in 2003 for illegally raising funds in [[Huazhou, Guangdong|Huazhou]], Maoming.<ref name=cnstock>{{cite web|url=http://news.cnstock.com/industry,cyqb-201611-3957988.htm|title=AC米兰的神秘买家|date=23 November 2016|access-date=15 April 2017|work=上海证券报|agency=Xinhua News Agency|language=Chinese}}</ref> According to legal proceeding, Li family had set up a company in mainland China as Jade Valley Development ({{zh|s=绿色山河开发}}) to invest in farmland. However, they also made false dividend forecast to attract investment as a [[pyramid scheme]].<ref name=legal>[http://www.eduzhai.net/falv/902/958/falv_320261.html 化州市公安局起诉意见书 化公诉字(2004)22号] (in Chinese)</ref>
According to the legal proceeding and Hong Kong Companies Registry, Li family had set up a Hong Kong company '''Jade Valley Group Limited''' ({{zh|t=綠色山河集團有限公司}}, formerly known as ''Lis Consortium (International) Limited''; {{lang|zh|利事集團投資有限公司}}) to channel the assets, which was 95% owned by Li Yonghong's eldest brother Li Hongqiang ({{zh|s=李洪强}}); the rest of the share was owned by a Honduras citizen, with unknown relation with Li family.<ref name=legal/><ref name=HKCR/> Chinese police failed to arrest Li Hongqiang as he also had Hong Kong citizenship<ref name=HKCR/> and evaded from mainland China.<ref name=legal/> It was reported that Li Hongqiang had emigrated to Honduras.<ref name=163report/> Jade Valley Group Limited was dissolved by striking off from the register by the government of Hong Kong in 2005.<ref>http://www.gld.gov.hk/egazette/pdf/20050911/egn200509111226.pdf</ref>
According to ''1993 Hainan Yearbook'', Li family's Jade Valley Group Limited incorporated two subsidiaries in [[Hainan]] ({{zh|s=海南首力房地产开发有限公司|l=Hainan Chief Power Real Estate Development Co., Ltd.}} and {{zh|s=海口首力酒店有限公司|l=Haikou Chief Power Hotel Co., Ltd.}}), to develop Chief Power Building ({{zh|s=首力大厦|p=Shǒulì Dàshà}}), which Li Yonghong was the general manager<ref>{{cite book|title=1993 Hainan Yearbook|publisher=Hainan Yearbook Editorial Board|language=Chinese}}</ref> and his eldest brother Li Hongqiang as the chairman. In 2010 Chief Power Real Estate was dissolved by strike-off from the registry by the administration bureau, as the bureau failed to inspect the company.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://aic.hainan.gov.cn/web/www/s104.html|title=限期年检的公告|date=17 December 2007|access-date=6 June 2017|publisher=Industrial & Commercial Administration Bureau of Hainan Province|language=Chinese}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release|url=http://gsj.hinews.cn/system/2010/07/01/010923643.shtml|title=听证公告|date=24 February 2010|access-date=6 June 2017|publisher=Industrial & Commercial Administration Bureau of Hainan Province|language=Chinese|format=hosted in hinews.cn}}</ref> Chief Power Hotel Co., Ltd. was also involved in numerous legal dispute with others, including the selling of a unit in Chief Power Building without disclosing the unit had been mortgaged,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fwcqlsz.com/art/view.asp?id=878656089411|title=从公证撤销看一起撤回房产预售申请不予备案决定案 |date=31 March 2017|access-date=6 June 2017|publisher=Beijing Kenuo Law Firm|language=Chinese}}</ref> contract dispute with a pawn shop in the sell and bought back of a unit of Chief Power Building,<ref>海口首力酒店有限公司诉海口百邦典当行借款合同纠纷案 （２００１）海中法民终字第１９号 Hainan Middle Court (in Chinese)</ref> and fail to repayment of loans to [[China Construction Bank]] (the bad debt was later transferred to [[China Cinda Asset Management]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://finance.jrj.com.cn/2017/05/24044022522416.shtml|title=债权转让公告 |date=24 May 2017|access-date=6 June 2017|publisher=China Cinda Asset Management, Hubei Branch|language=Chinese|format=re-published in jrj.com.cn}}</ref> and [[China Investment Bank]] (for [[United States dollar|US$]]1.1 million; the bank business was received by [[China CITIC Bank]]).<ref>{{lang|zh|中国光大银行武汉分行诉海南首力房地产开发有限公司借款合同纠纷案 海南省海口市中级人民法院}} (in Chinese)</ref> Chief Power Hotel Co., Ltd. was also suffered from a scam that another person falsify a document to sell unit A2 of 12/F of Chief Power Building.<ref>{{lang|zh|（2013）刑事判决书 龙刑初字第141号 海口市龙华区人民法院}} (in Chinese)</ref>
===Duolun Industry=== Li Yonghong was also sanctioned {{CNY|600,000}} in 2013 by the Chinese regulator [[China Securities Regulatory Commission]] for failing to disclose the sale of the entire share capital of the parent company of a Chinese listed company [[P2P Financial Information Service|Shanghai Duolun Industry Co., Ltd.]] ({{SSE|600696}}, now known as "P2P Financial Information Service Co., Ltd.").<ref name=csrc/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/chinese-businessman-buying-ac-milan-was-penalized-over-stock-sale-1473333297 |title=Chinese Businessman Buying AC Milan Was Penalized Over Stock Sale |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=8 September 2016 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref>
The holding company, known as "Duolun Investment (Hong Kong) Co., Ltd." at that time (now known as "P2P (China) Co., Ltd.") was incorporated in Hong Kong. The holding company owned 11.75% shares of the listed company as the largest shareholder at 31 December 2011.<ref name=csrc/><ref name=Duolun2011AR>{{cite web|url=http://static.sse.com.cn/disclosure/listedinfo/announcement/c/2012-03-20/600696_2011_n.pdf|title=2011 Annual Report|date=20 March 2012|access-date=13 April 2017|work=Duolun Industry|publisher=Shanghai Stock Exchange|language=Chinese}}</ref> Li Yonghong acquired the holding company in December 2011 for {{CNY|360 million}}<ref name=Duolun2011/> and sold in May–June 2012 for {{CNY|340 million}}.<ref name=csrc/> Before the deal, the holding company had already faced financial difficulties, which pledged 11.75% shares of the listed company to [[Bohai Trust]] in October 2011,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://static.sse.com.cn/disclosure/listedinfo/announcement/c/2011-10-22/600696_20111022_1.pdf|title=大股东股权质押的公告|date=22 October 2011|access-date=13 April 2017|work=Duolun Industry|publisher=Shanghai Stock Exchange|language=Chinese}}</ref> as well as selling a further 15.22% shares from April to September 2011<ref>{{cite web|url=http://static.sse.com.cn/disclosure/listedinfo/announcement/c/2011-09-21/600696_20110921_2.pdf|title=简式权益变动报告书|date=21 September 2011|access-date=13 April 2017|work=Duolun Industry|publisher=Shanghai Stock Exchange|language=Chinese}}</ref> and an additional 9.53% shares in November 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://static.sse.com.cn/disclosure/listedinfo/announcement/c/2011-11-19/600696_20111119_2.pdf|title=简式权益变动报告书|date=19 November 2011|access-date=13 April 2017|work=Duolun Industry|publisher=Shanghai Stock Exchange|language=Chinese}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://static.sse.com.cn/disclosure/listedinfo/announcement/c/2011-11-24/600696_20111124_1.pdf|title=关于大股东减持公司股份的公告|date=24 November 2011|access-date=13 April 2017|work=Duolun Industry|publisher=Shanghai Stock Exchange|language=Chinese}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://static.sse.com.cn/disclosure/listedinfo/announcement/c/2011-11-25/600696_20111125_1.pdf|title=关于大股东减持公司股份的公告|date=25 November 2011|access-date=13 April 2017|work=Duolun Industry|publisher=Shanghai Stock Exchange|language=Chinese}}</ref> A pledge of 35.82% shares of the listed company<ref>{{cite web|url=http://static.sse.com.cn/disclosure/listedinfo/announcement/c/2011-04-01/600696_2010_n.pdf|title=2010 Annual Report|date=1 April 2011|access-date=13 April 2017|work=Duolun Industry|publisher=Shanghai Stock Exchange|language=Chinese}}</ref> (to [[Hua Xia Bank]] and [[New China Trust]]) were only released in April<ref>{{cite web|url=http://static.sse.com.cn/disclosure/listedinfo/announcement/c/2011-04-13/600696_20110413_1.pdf|title=大股东股权解押的公告|date=13 April 2011|access-date=13 April 2017|work=Duolun Industry|publisher=Shanghai Stock Exchange|language=Chinese}}</ref> and September 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://static.sse.com.cn/disclosure/listedinfo/announcement/c/2011-09-10/600696_20110910_1.pdf|title=大股东股权解押的公告|date=10 September 2011|access-date=13 April 2017|work=Duolun Industry|publisher=Shanghai Stock Exchange|language=Chinese}}</ref>
In July 2013, the pledge of the 11.75% share of the listed company by the holding company was released by Bohai Trust. However, the holding company, under the new owner Xian Yan ({{zh|s=鲜言}}), pledged the entire 11.75% shares back to Li Yonghong.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://static.sse.com.cn/disclosure/listedinfo/announcement/c/2013-07-08/600696_20130709_1.pdf|title=大股东股权解押及质押的公告|date=9 July 2013|access-date=13 April 2017|work=Duolun Industry|publisher=Shanghai Stock Exchange|language=Chinese}}</ref> Half of the pledged shares were released in April 2014 and May 2014, only sold by the holding company on the same day. In August 2014, the shares pledged to Li Yonghong were released, only re-pledged to [[Ping An Securities]] on the same day.
According to a news report by ''[[China Securities Journal]]'', Chen Jianyong ({{zh|s=陈建勇}}) and Xian Li ({{zh|s=鲜栗}}), the relatives of Li Yonghong and Xian Yan respectively, had formed two companies ({{zh|s=广东鸿远能源投资}} and {{zh|s=湖北精九投资}}) respectively, which were the investors in a private equity fund (as a [[Trust law|trust]]) to buy the shares of Duolun Industry, which was accused by other investor ({{zh|s=江苏沐雪}}) of the fund as insider trading.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://finance.sina.com.cn/money/smjj/20130227/005914654309.shtml|title=私募沐雪巴菲特一号纠纷追踪：谁的资本玩偶|date=27 February 2013|access-date=15 April 2017|work=China Securities Journal |publisher=Re-published by sina|language=Chinese}}</ref>
===Using alias=== According to news report by ''Securities Times'' (a newspaper of "[[People's Daily]] Press"), Li Yonghong may used an alias '''Li Bingfeng''' ({{zh|s=李秉峰}}) to do business in some companies, such as Beijing Dahe Zhizhou Group ({{zh|s=北京大河之洲集团}}) and Li family's Chief Power Real Estate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.stcn.com/2013/0730/10639328.shtml|title=多伦股份幕后玩家指向大河系 看似平行的交叉线|date=30 July 2013|access-date=6 June 2017|work=Securities Times|language=Chinese}}</ref><ref name=163report>{{cite web|url=http://money.163.com/special/view719/|title=AC米兰玩家李勇鸿:或曾列入非法集资追逃名单|date=30 September 2016|access-date=15 April 2017|publisher=163.com|language=Chinese}}</ref>
===Grand Dragon International Holding=== Li Yonghong alleged himself as the chairman of Hong Kong-incorporated Grand Dragon International Holdings ({{zh|t=龍浩國際集團|l=Longhao International Group}}).<ref name=Duolun2011/> The company falsely claimed itself as the official Chinese side representative to build the [[Thai Canal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/world/2015-05/20/c_127819248.htm|title= 揭秘"中泰签署克拉运河合作备忘录"的背后 |date=20 May 2015|access-date=15 April 2017|agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|language=Chinese}}</ref>
In 2017 a press release of Grand Dragon International Holding was appeared in the website of another company Guangdong Longhao Aviation Group ({{zh|s=广东龙浩航空集团}}), denying Li was the chairman of Grand Dragon International Holdings in anytime.<ref name=NYT2017/><ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.longhao-air.com/index.php?c=article&a=detail&id=215|script-title=zh:澄清声明|trans-title=Clarification|date=10 June 2017|access-date=21 November 2017|publisher= Grand Dragon International Holdings|via=longhao-air.com}}</ref> === List of Dishonest Judgment Debtors=== On 12 September 2018, Li was added to the ''List of Dishonest Judgment Debtors'' ({{zh|s=失信被执行人名单}}) by the local court of [[Jingmen]].<ref name=court/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bjnews.com.cn/finance/2018/10/22/512976.html|script-title=zh:AC米兰旧主李勇鸿被限出入境 牵出神秘资本圈|newspaper=新京报 [The Beijing News]|language=zh-cn|date=22 October 2018|accessdate=29 October 2018|author=赵毅波 [Zhao Yibo]|editor=马小龙}}</ref> According to the press release, Li defaulted a loan from aforementioned Hubei Jingjiu ({{zh|s=湖北精九|p=Húběi Jīngjiǔ}}).<ref name=court>{{cite press release|url=http://jmzy.hbfy.gov.cn/WenshuManage/ViewWenshu?id=799f6aa7-4dfe-4ffc-a0af-a96b0130ac19|script-title=zh:湖北精九投资有限公司、李勇鸿金融借款合同纠纷执行实施类执行裁定书 |date=12 September 2018|accessdate=18 October 2018|publisher=湖北省荆门市中级人民法院|language=zh-cn}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links ==

revision.text:
This is a list of companies having stocks that are included in the '''[[S&P 400]]''' [[stock market index]]. The index, maintained by [[S&P Dow Jones Indices]], comprises the common stocks of 400 [[market capitalization|mid-cap]], mostly American, companies.

==Recent and announced changes to the list of S&P 400 Components==
<!-- EDITORS PLEASE TAKE NOTE:
If you are updating the following table due to a change which occurred in the components of the S&P 400 please consider the following.
1. S&P never adds or removes a stock in isolation, it's always "AAA replaces BBB". Please do not simply add or remove a component; Rather, make sure you record both parts of the change.
2. If you record a change here, please also make the corresponding changes in the above table "S&P 400 Component Stocks" Keeping these two tables in sync should make it much easier for editors to keep track of which changes have/haven't been entered.
3. Company name changes or ticker changes are not changes to the index and should not be in this table.
Thanks! -->

(NYSE: VZ) acquired AOL.<ref name="casy_aol">{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/columbia-pipeline-to-join-the-sp-500-other-changes-to-sp-midcap-400--sp-smallcap-600-300104046.html | title=Columbia Pipeline to Join the S&P 500; Other Changes to S&P MidCap 400 & S&P SmallCap 600}}</ref> |- | June 11, 2015 || WETF || [[WisdomTree Investments]] || QRVO || [[Qorvo]] || Qorvo Inc. replaced Lorillard Inc. in the S&P 500 due to Lorillard being acquired by Reynolds American Inc. |- | June 29, 2015 || CBRL || [[Cracker Barrel]] || DRC || [[Dresser-Rand Group]] || Siemens AG acquired Dresser-Rand Group.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/cracker-barrel-old-country-store-set-to-join-the-sp-midcap-400-marten-transport-to-be-added-to-sp-smallcap-600-300106448.html | title=Cracker Barrel Old Country Store Set to Join the S&P MidCap 400; Marten Transport to be Added to S&P SmallCap 600}}</ref> |- | June 10, 2015 || MANH || [[Manhattan Associates Inc.]] || LTM || [[Life Time Fitness Inc.]] || Life Time Fitness is now a private company. |- |June 1, 2015 || TLN || [[Talen Energy]] || WIN || [[Windstream]] || Talen spun off by PPL Corp (NYSE:PPL); Windstream bumped due to market cap rank<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.spice-indices.com/idpfiles/spice-assets/resources/public/documents/184743_spinppl5.pdf?force_download=true | title=Talen Energy Set to Join the S&P MidCap 400}}</ref> |- |May 29, 2015 || OZRK || [[Bank of the Ozarks]] || XLS || [[Exelis]] || S&P 500 constituent Harris Corp. (NYSE:HRS) acquired Exelis.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.spice-indices.com/idpfiles/spice-assets/resources/public/documents/186742_4xlsozrkha6.pdf?force_download=true | title=Bank of the Ozarks Set to Join the S&P MidCap 400}}</ref> |- |April 27, 2015 || DNKN || [[Dunkin' Brands|Dunkin' Brands Group Inc]] || RVBD || [[Riverbed Technology Inc]] || Riverbed Technology acquired by group led by Thoma Bravo LLC<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.spice-indices.com/idpfiles/spice-assets/resources/public/documents/168966_dunkinriver4entropicwalker6.pdf?force_download=true | title=Dunkin’ Brands Group Set to Join the S&P MidCap 400}}</ref> |- |April 24, 2015 || CSAL || [[Communications Sales & Leasing]] || CLF || [[Cliffs Natural Resources]] || Communications Sales & Leasing spun off by Windstream Holdings; Cliffs Natural Resources removed due to Market Cap adjustments<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.spice-indices.com/idpfiles/spice-assets/resources/public/documents/171544_spinwin4.pdf?force_download=true | title=Communications Sales & Leasing Set to Join the S&P MidCap 400}}</ref> |- |April 7, 2015 || CNO || [[CNO Financial Group]] || SLXP || [[Salix Pharmaceuticals]] || Salix Pharmaceuticals acquired by Valeant Pharmaceuticals (NYSE:VRX).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.spice-indices.com/idpfiles/spice-assets/resources/public/documents/163742_salixcno1.pdf?force_download=true | title=CNO Financial Group Set to Join the S&P MidCap 400}}</ref> |- | September 30, 2014 || CDK || CDK Global Inc. || BBG || [[Bill Barrett Corporation]] || Bill Barrett’s market capitalization is below $1.2 billion |}

revision.text:
{{clean up|reason=repetitions, inline external links|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox Organization |image = Mafo14.png |caption = Career, Congress, Contact |type = [[Nonprofit organization|Not-for-profit (NGO)]]
[[Student society]] |leader_title = |leader_name = |formation = 2012 |purpose = Discussion platform for contemporary topics |language = English and German |status = Active |location = [[University of Mannheim]], [[Mannheim]], [[Germany]] |num_volunteers=>40 |website = [http://mannheim-forum.org/ mannheim-forum.org] }} The '''Mannheim Forum''' is an economic [[congress]] organized exclusively by students of the [[University of Mannheim]] and is among the largest collegiate events in Germany with more than 500 participants each year. During the Mannheim Forum various events take place on Mannheim's main [[campus]] - the [[Mannheim Palace]] in [[Mannheim]], [[Baden-Württemberg]], [[Germany]]. Besides topical speeches by renowned people, the participants also have the opportunity to attend the Recruiting Fair, as well as participate in several company [[workshops]]. During the panel discussions the audience can discuss with several top tier personalities from the worlds of [[business]], [[economics]], [[society]] and [[politics]]. Under the topic „(Without) Borders?“, the next Forum will take place, under the patronage of the [[States of Germany|state]] [[Baden-Württemberg]] and its [[Minister-President]] [[Winfried Kretschmann]].{{cite web|url=http://mannheim-forum.org/|title=Mannheim Forum - Official webpage|publisher=Mannheim Forum|accessdate=2013-12-11}}{{cite web|url=http://mannheim-forum.org/eu-schirmherrschaft|title=Mannheim Forum - EU Schirmherrschaft|publisher=Mannheim Forum|accessdate=2014-01-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201222800/http://mannheim-forum.org/eu-schirmherrschaft|archivedate=2014-02-01|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.handelsblatt-hochschulinitiative.com/index.php/veranstaltungen/partner-veranstaltungen.html|title=Partner-Veranstaltungen: Mannheim Forum|publisher=Handelsblatt|accessdate=2014-02-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140314115430/http://www.handelsblatt-hochschulinitiative.com/index.php/veranstaltungen/partner-veranstaltungen.html|archive-date=2014-03-14|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.studiumgenerale.uni-mannheim.de/de/initiativen/mannheimer_forum/mannheimer_forum_ev/|title=Mannheimer Initiative: Mannheim Forum e.V.|publisher=University of Mannheim|accessdate=2014-03-14}} == History == [[Image:Mannheim Forum 2014 Pic 2.jpg|thumb|right|180px|[[Frank Plasberg]], [[Paul Achleitner]] and [[Peer Steinbrück]] on Mannheim Forum 2014]] In 2012, the student initiative Mannheim Forum was founded by the three largest student initiatives at Mannheim's campus: [[Arbeitskreis Börse (AKB)]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20131202225149/http://www.mtp.org/mtp-site/regional/mannheim.nsf/id/pa_gs_start.html MTP - The Marketing Initiative], and [http://www.polimotion.de/ PoliMotion - The Politics Initiative].{{cite web|url=http://mannheim-forum.org/gruendungsinitiativen|title=Mannheim Forum - Gründungsinitiativen|publisher=Mannheim Forum|accessdate=2013-11-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203005304/http://mannheim-forum.org/gruendungsinitiativen|archive-date=2013-12-03|dead-url=yes|df=}} The idea and goal behind the initiative was to establish an event that enable participants and students of different branches of study to engage in dynamic dialog with representatives of politics, science and economics about specific issues that are relevant in today's world. The first event organized by the initiative was the panel discussion in 2012 between Mannheim professors of different disciplines and company representatives about the topic "EU - Economic Poliy - Quo Vadis?!". The event received positive responses from both students and participants alike. From then on, the students'aim was to establish this event on a larger scale under the name "Mannheim Forum" as a fixed annual event at the University of Mannheim. The first "Mannheim Forum" was then conducted in 2013 under the topic of “Resources – 6 Perspectives: Economy, Ethics, Security, Politics, Technology and Startups”, and was followed by annual events in the years 2014-2016, the next event will take place in spring 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.sp-dozenten.de/index.php?mod=news&id=449|title=Mannheim Forum 2014|publisher=Schäffer-Poeschel Verlag|accessdate=2014-01-29}}{{cite web|url=http://www.akboerse.de/vortrag-archiv+M503073053eb.html|title=Mannheim Forum 2013|publisher=AK Börse|accessdate=2014-01-29}} == Organization == [[Image:Mannheim Forum 2014 Pic 1.jpg|thumb|right|120px|Mannheim Forum 2014 flag in front of the [[University of Mannheim]]]] Mannheim Forum is mainly organized by students in their first and second academic term (nevertheless it is open to every student at UMA) bringing in new ideas and fresh perspectives, but are supported and financed by external partners, including [[McKinsey & Co.]], [[SAP AG]], [[PWC]], [[Roland Berger Strategy Consultants]], [[Lufthansa]], [[Reckitt Benckiser]], [[HSBC]], [[Deloitte]], [[Heidelberg Cement]], [[Hoffmann-La Roche]] as well as the [[Mannheim Business School]] and alumni - who ensure that knowledge based on experience is used and implemented.{{cite web|url=http://mannheim-forum.org/partner|title=Mannheim Forum - EU Partnership|publisher=Mannheim Forum|accessdate=2014-01-17}} Furthermore, the Mannheim Forum holds close cooperations with other student initiatives at the University of Mannheim, like MTP, Arbeitskreis Börse and POLImotion.{{cite web|url=http://mannheim-forum.org/ueber-uns|title=Mannheim Forum - About us|publisher=Mannheim Forum|accessdate=2014-01-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140125022007/http://www.mannheim-forum.org/ueber-uns|archive-date=2014-01-25|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.goetzpartners.com/de/karriere/treffen-sie-goetzpartners/mannheim-forum/|title=Treffen Sie Goetzpartners beim Mannheim Forum/|publisher=Goetzpartners|accessdate=2014-01-17}} == Topics of former conferences == * 2016: ''(Ohne) Grenzen?'' ((Without) Borders?) * 2015: ''ZeitFragen'' (Time Questions: Politics, Economy, Society and Science) * 2014: ''Macht und Verteilung'' (Power - Who possess power? Is there a fair distribution of power in today's world?) * 2013: ''Ressourcen und Nachhaltigkeit'' (Resources and Sustainability) * 2012: ''EU - Wirtschaftspolitik- Quo Vadis?'' (EU - Economic Poliy - Quo Vadis?) == Selected speakers == In the past the Mannheim Forum was host to speakers from a broad range of fields, speakers included:{{cite web|url=https://www.mannheim-forum.org/mannheim-forum/programm/hauptveranstaltungen|title=Mannheim Forum 2016: Programm|publisher=Mannheim Forum|accessdate=2016-01-01|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219022551/https://www.mannheim-forum.org/mannheim-forum/programm/hauptveranstaltungen|archive-date=2015-02-19|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.mannheim-forum.org/mannheim-forum/programm|title=Mannheim Forum 2015: Programm|publisher=Mannheim Forum|accessdate=2014-01-17}}{{cite web|url=https://www.mannheim-forum.org/programm_2013|title=Mannheim Forum 2013: Programm|publisher=Mannheim Forum|accessdate=2015-01-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218215331/https://www.mannheim-forum.org/programm_2013|archive-date=2015-02-18|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.mannheim-forum.org/sites/default/files/images/rueckblick/2014_timetable.pdf|title=Mannheim Forum 2014: Programm|publisher=Mannheim Forum|accessdate=2014-01-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218222304/https://www.mannheim-forum.org/sites/default/files/images/rueckblick/2014_timetable.pdf|archive-date=2015-02-18|dead-url=yes|df=}} {| style="width:100%;" |- | style="vertical-align:top; width:33%;"| * [[Hamed Abdel-Samad]] * [[Paul Achleitner]] * [[Josef Ackermann]] * [[Sabine Bendiek]] (CEO, Microsoft Germany){{cite web|url=http://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/Microsoft-Sabine-Bendiek-wird-neue-Deutschland-Chefin-2864871.html|title=Microsoft: Sabine Bendiek wird neue Deutschland-Chefin|publisher=heise.de|accessdate=2016-01-01}} * [[Peter Bofinger]] * [[Walter Gunz]] (Co-founder of [[Media Markt]]){{cite web|url=http://www.zeit.de/2014/04/media-markt-erich-kellerhals-metro|title=Der sture Milliardär|publisher=Die Zeit|accessdate=2015-02-17}} * [[Gregor Gysi]] | style="vertical-align:top; width:33%;"| * [[Albrecht Hornbach]] (Chairman of [[Hornbach (hypermarket)|Hornbach]]) * [[Christian Lindner]] * [[Frank Mattern]] (CEO, McKinsey & Co. Germany){{cite web|url=https://www.handelsblatt.com/unternehmen/management/deutschland-chef-mattern-steigt-bei-mckinsey-auf/8911868.html|title=Mattern steigt bei McKinsey auf|publisher=Handelsblatt|accessdate=2015-02-17}} * [[Dirk Müller (broker)|Dirk Müller]] (German broker, known as "Mister Dax") * [[Frank Plasberg]] * [[Thomas Maria Renz]] * [[Bert Rürup]] | style="vertical-align:top; width:33%;"| * [[Michael Schmidt-Salomon]] * [[Peter Sloterdijk]] * [[Peer Steinbrück]] * [[Hans von Storch]] * [[Sahra Wagenknecht]] * [[Götz Werner]] |} == See also == * [[University of Mannheim]] * [[Mannheim]] * [[Mannheim Business School]] ==External links== {{Commons category|Universität Mannheim}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v4czgR1d3UE Mannheim Forum 2014 Imagetrailer] * [https://de-de.facebook.com/MannheimForum Mannheim Forum Facebook Page] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080704001923/http://www.uni-mannheim.de/english/index.html Universität Mannheim (English webpage)] * [http://www.uni-mannheim.de/ Universität Mannheim (German webpage)] == Reception == * Pflichtlektüre: Von Postkarten bis Daten sammeln: Wissen ist Macht, Online Article, March 14, 2014, Mannheim Forum 2014 [http://www.pflichtlektuere.com/14/03/2014/von-postkarten-bis-daten-sammeln-wissen-ist-macht/ Online] * MorgenWeb: Von Bankbeamten, Boni und billigem Wein, Online Article, March 15, 2014, Mannheim Forum 2014 [https://web.archive.org/web/20140319002536/http://www.morgenweb.de/nachrichten/sudwest/von-bankbeamten-boni-und-billigem-wein-1.1442909?no-device-check Online] * Mannheimer Morgen: Mit den Chinesen wachsen, Online Article, March 15, 2014, Mannheim Forum 2014 [https://web.archive.org/web/20140319025508/http://www.morgenweb.de/nachrichten/wirtschaft/regionale-wirtschaft/mit-den-chinesen-wachsen-1.1444836?no-device-check Online] ==Notes and references== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Universität Mannheim}} [[Category:University of Mannheim]] [[Category:Economy of Germany]] [[Category:Business conferences]] [[Category:International conferences in Germany]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/2402:8100:302B:950C:75E2:8891:BE5A:54CD|2402:8100:302B:950C:75E2:8891:BE5A:54CD]] ([[User talk:2402:8100:302B:950C:75E2:8891:BE5A:54CD|talk]]) to last version by ClueBot NG
revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Usage share (disambiguation)}} '''Market share''' is the percentage of a [[Market (economics)|market]] (defined in terms of either units or revenue) accounted for by a specific entity. In a survey of nearly 200 senior marketing managers, 67% responded that they found the revenue- "dollar market share" metric very useful, while 61% found "unit market share" very useful.<ref name=Marketing_Metrics>Farris, Paul W.; Neil T. Bendle; Phillip E. Pfeifer; David J. Reibstein (2010). ''Marketing Metrics: The Definitive Guide to Measuring Marketing Performance.'' Upper Saddle River, New Jersey: Pearson Education, Inc. {{ISBN|0137058292}}. The [[Marketing Accountability Standards Board (MASB)]] endorses the definitions, purposes, and constructs of classes of measures that appear in ''Marketing Metrics'' as part of its ongoing [http://www.commonlanguage.wikispaces.net/ Common Language in Marketing Project].</ref>
"Marketers need to be able to translate and incorporate sales targets into market share because this will demonstrate whether forecasts are to be attained by growing with the market or by capturing share from competitors. The latter will almost always be more difficult to achieve. Market share is closely monitored for signs of change in the competitive landscape, and it frequently drives strategic or tactical action."<ref name=Marketing_Metrics2>Farris, Paul W.; Neil T. Bendle; Phillip E. Pfeifer; David J. Reibstein (2010). ''Marketing Metrics: The Definitive Guide to Measuring Marketing Performance.'' Upper Saddle River, New Jersey: Pearson Education, Inc. {{ISBN|0137058292}}. The [[Marketing Accountability Standards Board (MASB)]] endorses the definitions, purposes, and constructs of classes of measures that appear in ''Marketing Metrics'' as part of its ongoing [http://www.themasb.org/projects/underway/ Common Language: Marketing Activities and Metrics Project].</ref>
Increasing market share is one of the most important objectives of [[business]]. The main advantage of using market share as a measure of business performance is that it is less dependent upon [[environmental scanning|macro environmental variables]] such as the state of the economy or changes in [[tax policy]].
In the [[United States]] market, however, increasing market share may be dangerous for makers of [[fungibility|fungible]] and potentially hazardous products such as medicine, due to a US-only legal doctrine called [[market share liability]].
== Purpose ==
Market share is said to be a key indicator of market competitiveness—that is, how well a firm is doing against its competitors. "This metric, supplemented by changes in sales revenue, helps managers evaluate both primary and selective demand in their market. That is, it enables them to judge not only total market growth or decline but also trends in customers’ selections among competitors. Generally, sales growth resulting from primary demand (total market growth) is less costly and more profitable than that achieved by capturing share from competitors. Conversely, losses in market share can signal serious long-term problems that require strategic adjustments. Firms with market shares below a certain level may not be viable. Similarly, within a firm’s product line, market share trends for individual products are considered early indicators of future opportunities or problems."<ref name=Marketing_Metrics/>
Research has also shown that market share is a desired asset among competing firms.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://marketing.wharton.upenn.edu/files/?whdmsaction=public:main.file&fileID=685 | title = Competitor-oriented Objectives: The Myth of Market Share | author = J. Scott Armstrong and Kesten C. Greene | journal = International Journal of Business | volume = 12 | issue = 1 | pages = 116–134 | year = 2007 | ISSN= 1083-4346}}</ref> Experts, however, discourage making market share an objective and criterion upon which to base economic policies.<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://marketing.wharton.upenn.edu/ideas/pdf/armstrong2/compet.pdf | title = Competitor Orientation: Effects of Objectives and Information on Managerial Decisions and Profitability | author = J. Scott Armstrong and Fred Collopy | journal = Journal of Marketing Research | volume = 23 | pages = 188–199 | year = 1996 | publisher = American Marketing Association | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101217085359/http://marketing.wharton.upenn.edu/ideas/pdf/armstrong2/compet.pdf | archivedate = 2010-12-17 | df = | doi=10.2307/3152146}}</ref> The aforementioned usage of market share as a basis for gauging the performance of competing firms has fostered a system in which firms make decisions with regard to their operation with careful consideration of the impact of each decision on the market share of their competitors.
It is generally necessary to commission [[market research]] (generally [[secondary research|desk/secondary research]]) to determine. Sometimes, though, one can use [[primary research]] to estimate the total market size and a company's market share.
== Construction == "'''Market share:''' ''The percentage of a market accounted for by a specific entity.''"<ref name=Marketing_Metrics />
"'''Unit market share:''' ''The units sold by a particular company as a percentage of total market sales, measured in the same units.''"<ref name=Marketing_Metrics />
:Unit market share (%) = 100 * Unit sales (#) / Total Market Unit Sales (#)
"This formula, of course, can be rearranged to derive either unit sales or total market unit sales from the other two variables, as illustrated in the following:"<ref name=Marketing_Metrics />
:Unit sales (#) = Unit market share (%) * Total Market Unit Sales (#) / 100
:Total Market Unit Sales (#) = 100 * Unit sales (#) / Unit market share (%)
"'''Revenue market share:''' ''Revenue market share differs from unit market share in that it reflects the prices at which goods are sold. In fact, a relatively simple way to calculate relative price is to divide revenue market share by unit market share.''"<ref name=Marketing_Metrics />
:Revenue market share (%) = 100 * Sales Revenue ($) / Total Market Sales Revenue($)
"As with the unit market share, this equation for revenue market share can be rearranged to calculate either sales revenue or total market sales revenue from the other two variables."<ref name=Marketing_Metrics />
Market share can be decomposed into three components, namely: penetration share, share of customer, and usage index. These three underlying metrics can then be used to help the brand identify market share growth opportunities.<ref>Fripp, Geoff.[http://www.marketingstudyguide.com/how-to-decompose-market-share-video/ “Decomposing Market Share”] The Marketing Study Guide</ref>
== Methodologies == "Although market share is likely the single most important marketing metric, there is no generally acknowledged best method for calculating it. This is unfortunate, as different methods may yield not only different computations of market share at a given moment, but also widely divergent trends over time. The reasons for these disparities include variations in the lenses through which share is viewed (units versus dollars), where in the channel the measurements are taken (shipments from manufacturers versus consumer purchases), market definition (scope of the competitive universe), and measurement error."<ref name=Marketing_Metrics />
== See also == *[[Usage share (disambiguation)]] *[[Market value]] *[[Market power]] *[[Market share analysis]]
== References == {{dual|source=''Marketing Metrics: The Definitive Guide to Measuring Marketing Performance'' by Farris, Bendle, Pfeifer and Reibstein|sourcepath=https://books.google.com/books?id=7Ptw4nBoGmkC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Marketing+Metrics:+The+Definitive+Guide+to+Measuring+Marketing+Performance&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Uj18T-6LKtH6ggekmYTZCw&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Marketing%20Metrics%3A%20The%20Definitive%20Guide%20to%20Measuring%20Marketing%20Performance&f=false|date=April 10, 2012}} {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Marketing performance measurement]] [[Category:Marketing strategy]] [[Category:Market structure]]

revision.comment: media subcategories
revision.text:
'''Mass finishing''' is a group of [[manufacturing]] processes that allow large quantities of parts to be simultaneously [[finishing (manufacturing)|finished]]. The goal of this type of finishing is to [[burnishing (metal)|burnish]], [[burr (metal)|deburr]], clean, radius, [[flash (manufacturing)|de-flash]], [[descaling|descale]], remove [[rust]], polish, brighten, [[surface harden]], prepare parts for further finishing, or break off [[die cast]] runners. The two main types of mass finishing are [[tumble finishing]], also known as barrel finishing, and [[vibratory finishing]].<ref name="degarmo781,784">Degarmo, pp. 781–784.</ref> Both involve the use of a cyclical action to create grinding contact between surfaces. Sometimes the workpieces are finished against each other; however, usually a finishing medium is used. Mass finishing can be performed dry or wet; wet processes have liquid [[lubricant]]s, cleaners, or [[abrasive]]s, while dry processes do not. Cycle times can be as short as 10 minutes for [[nonferrous]] workpieces or as long as 2 hours for [[hardened steel]].<ref name="degarmo781,784"/>
Mass finishing processes can be configured as either batch systems, in which batches of workpieces are added, run, and removed before the next batch is run, or as continuous systems, in which the workpieces enter at one end and leave at the other end in the finished state. They may also be sequenced, which involves running the workpieces through multiple different mass finishing processes; usually, the finish becomes progressively finer. Due to the random action of the processes, mass finishing is as much an art as it is a science.<ref name="degarmo784">Degarmo, p. 784.</ref>
==Types== ===Tumble finishing=== {{main|Tumble finishing}}
===Vibratory finishing=== {{main|Vibratory finishing}}
==Media== ===Functions of Media=== Media are designed for four things:
;Cut: Media which cut can remove burrs and can smooth surfaces. As a carrier of abrasive grain, the large medium pieces effectively increase the impact force of the abrasive on the metal part to be cut, thereby improving the efficiency of the abrasive. Cutting media develop dull, [[Gloss (material appearance)|matte]] surfaces.
;[[Lustre (mineralogy)|Luster]]: Some grades of medium are designed to promote luster on the surface of metal parts. These products are generally non-abrasive or have a very low degree of abrasiveness. They deburr by [[peening]], rather than actually removing the burr. Media selection, therefore, will control the degree of surface luster, making the part bright and shiny or developing a very matte, dull surface characterized by a completely random scratch pattern, or anything in between.
;Part separation: A very important function of the medium is to separate parts during the deburring, cutting, surface improving or burnishing operations. The media:parts volume ratio is normally used to control the amount of part-on-part contact which will occur in a vibratory or tumble finishing operation. At low ratios, considerable part-on-part contact occurs, while at higher ratios part-on-part contact is limited.
;Surface scrubbing: Media have the unique ability to scrub surfaces and physically assist compounds in their cleaning function. Both abrasive and non-abrasive media are effective in this. They can remove organic soils, scale, and other inorganic residues. Media come in a wide range of materials in order to fulfill various needs.
===Types of Media===
;Aluminum media: [[Aluminium]] media are typically [[casting|cast part]]s and are available in a wide variety of shapes and sizes. Aluminum scrubs parts and can work in conjunction with cleaning compounds to clean parts. Since aluminum is fairly nonabrasive it tends to remove surface impurities without affecting the part's surface qualities. Its cost is typically higher than other cast media. Wear rates are lower than [[ceramic]] but higher than steel media.
;Preformed ceramic media: Ceramic media are manufactured by mixing clay-like materials and water with abrasives, forming the mud into shapes, drying the shapes, and [[pottery firing|firing]] them at high temperatures to [[vitrify]] the binder. Many of these binders are [[porcelain]]-like in nature. Variability in these products occur both with the type of binder used, firing temperatures, the amount, size and type of abrasive grains they contain, and their uniformity of firing. This type of media today is the general workhorse of mass finishing systems and is the type of medium generally used, because of its availability in a variety of shapes and sizes, low cost, and low wear rate.
;Preformed resin-bonded media: Plastic or [[resin]]-bonded media utilize a wider range of abrasive types and sizes than preformed ceramics. The most popular grades are those using [[quartz]] as an abrasive. [[Aluminum oxide]], [[silicon carbide]] and other abrasives are also used. Usually, low-cost [[polyester]] resins are employed as the binder and the various shapes are produced by casting. Resin bonded media is good for preparing a metal surface for [[plating]].
;Steel: [[Case hardened]], stress-relieved steel preformed shapes are available in a variety of sizes and configurations. Balls, balls with flat spots, ovoids (footballs), diagonally cut wire similar to angle-cut cylinders, ball cones and cones (both of which are different from the general concept of cones) and pins are the most commonly used. Steel media weigh approximately 300 pounds per cubic foot and are expensive for initial installation, but, because of their minimal attrition rate and extreme cleanliness, are being more widely used for light deburring applications and cleaning. Compounds are available to keep steel burnishing media clean and bright for extended periods.
;Synthetic random-shaped media: The most popular synthetic random media is [[melting|fused]] aluminum oxide, which is available in a number of grades. The more loosely bound, coarse-grained materials are characterized by fast cut and high depreciation rates. Because of the dark color of fused aluminum oxide, the soil generated by this material is excessive in many applications. Fine-grained fused aluminum oxide is generally employed for burnishing and in this respect is unexcelled in many applications with the possible exception of steel. Where some light cutting is required, fine-grained aluminum oxide can develop a better luster on stainless steels and other hard surfaces than can be achieved with steel burnishing media.
;Natural random-shaped media: River rock, [[granite]], [[quartz]], [[limestone]], [[emery (mineral)|emery]] and other naturally occurring abrasive materials are also used in vibratory and tumble finishing applications. In general, these media are not very efficient in vibratory equipment because of their high attrition rates.
;Cobmeal, walnut-shell flour, and related materials: These are used for drying applications because of the natural ability of these materials to absorb water from metal surfaces. These can also be blended with abrasives and used for fine-polishing applications in vibratory, barrel, or spindle finishing equipment.
;Other: [[Shoe peg]]s, leather, [[carpet tack]]s, and many other solid materials have been used at one time or another in tumble or vibratory finishing for certain applications.
==Compounds== Compounds are added to mass finishing processes to assist in deburring, burnishing, cutting, cleaning, descaling, and inhibiting [[corrosion]]. They may be liquids or dry powders. They are usually broken up into four types: deburring and finishing, burnishing, cleaning, and water stabilizing.<ref name="degarmo784"/>
;Deburring and finishing: These compounds are mainly designed to suspend the small particles created when deburring and abrading parts. They are also designed to keep workpieces clean and inhibit corrosion. ;Burnishing: Burnishing compounds are designed to enhance brightness and to develop certain colors after mass finishing. ;Cleaning: These compounds are usually dilute [[acid]]s or [[soap]]s designed to remove soil, grease, or oil from the incoming parts. They also provide corrosion resistance for ferrous and non-ferrous parts. ;Water stabilizers: These are used in conjunction with water to maintain a consistent [[water hardness]] and level of metal ions. This helps ensure consistent results from batch to batch.
==References== ===Notes=== "Mass Finishing Handbook" by LaRoux Gillespie, Society of Manufacturing Engineers, 2007 {{reflist}}
===Bibliography=== *{{Citation | last = Degarmo | first = E. Paul | last2 = Black | first2 = J T. | last3 = Kohser | first3 = Ronald A. | title = Materials and Processes in Manufacturing | publisher = Wiley | year = 2003 | edition = 9th | isbn = 0-471-65653-4}}.
[[Category:Industrial processes]] [[Category:Metalworking]]

'''Melvin C. Steen''' (1907–1992) was an American attorney and founding partner of the New York law firm [[Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton]].<ref>{{cite web|author=WOLFGANG SAXONPublished: June 30, 1992 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/06/30/nyregion/melvin-c-steen-85-a-founder-of-the-cleary-gottlieb-law-firm.html |title=Melvin C. Steen, 85, a Founder Of the Cleary, Gottlieb Law Firm - New York Times |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=1992-06-30 |accessdate=2012-06-07}}</ref> Steen graduated from the [[University of Minnesota Law School]], where the Melvin C. Steen Professorship, currently held by [[Gregory Shaffer]], is named in his honor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.law.umn.edu/facultyprofiles/shafferg.html |title=Gregory Shaffer - U of MN Law School |publisher=Law.umn.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-06-07}}</ref> His survivors included his son Gordon of [[Owings Mills, Maryland]].<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1992-07-01/news/1992183157_1_steen-gordon-r-bronxville |title=Melvin C. Steen, 85, a corporate and securities lawyer in... - Baltimore Sun |publisher=Articles.baltimoresun.com |date=1992-07-01 |accessdate=2012-06-07}}</ref>
Over the years, Steen's law partnerships have included [[Henry Friendly]] and [[George W. Ball]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/Cleary-Gottlieb-Steen-amp;-Hamilton-Company-History.html |title=Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton - Company History |publisher=Fundinguniverse.com |date= |accessdate=2012-06-07}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
